Amazing Proofs that indicate Ramayana actually happened!  The Ramayana: History or mythology? The Ramayana is one of two epics, the other being the Mahabharata, which have had a crucial influence in shaping the nature of Indian civilization. The Ramayana existed in the oral tradition perhaps as far back as 1,500 BCE, but the fourth century BCE is generally accepted as the date of its composition in Sanskrit by Sage Valmiki. Many historians claim that Ramayana actually happened and is not a mythological folklore. Here are few evidences that make a compelling case… 1/17  Cobra Hood cave, Sri Lanka The tradition states that Mata Sita was held in confinement in the Cobra Hood cave. There are many pre-historic drawings on its ceiling. An inscription in the cave that reads, ‘Parumaka naguliya lene’ further establishes a distinct link between Mata Sita and the Cobra Hood cave. The Demons who guarded Mata Sita while she was Ravana’s prisoner called her her Naguliya – one who was born off the ploughshare. 2/17  Existence of Hanuman Garhi Lord Hanuman is one of the most important characters of Ramayana and an ardent devotee of Lord Rama. Hanuman Garhi, now a temple is a place in Ayodhya, where Hanuman ji was waiting patiently for Lord Rama who was in exile. Hanuman Garhi temple is also famous for its strategic location. It is situated at such a height and at such a site, from where the sunrises and sunsets are artistically visible. 3/17  Foot Prints of Lord Hanuman When Hanuman ji reached at Ashok Vatika, he is said to have come in the form of a giant. There are giant footprints on one side of the lake there which are said to be Hanuman's footprints, formed when he landed there. 4/17  Ram Sethu It is estimated that 'Rama's Bridge' is constructed in around 5000 B.C, with the use of wood and stones. This supports the claim of Ramayana being Historical. It is also backed by the construction method used to build the bridge is mentioned in the Valmiki's text. 5/17  Sync between time history and ages Archaeological studies reveal that the first human inhabitation happened in Sri Lanka around 1,750,000 years ago and it’s been proved that the bridge’s age dates back to the same equivalent. To top it, the dates mentioned in the text of Valmiki matches with that of primitive age as well. 6/17  Mystery of Floating stones In Ramayan it is mentioned that the Ram Setu was built by Stones and these stone starts floating on water by touch of Nala & Neel. Some such stones were scattered at Rameshwaram during the Tsunami, these stones still float on water. Many Geologist says RAMA Setu is built by natural process but failed to provide enough proofs. Apart from The Ramayana there are several facts which say Rama Setu is a man-made Structure. 7/17  Sanjeevani Mountain, Dunagiri Lord Hanumana carried the entire mountain that had Sanjeevani Booti when Lakshmana lost his consciousness during the war with Indrajeet. This mountain was named as Dunagiri. In most re-tellings of The Ramayana, after the medicines were used, Hanuman flies again to replace the mountain in its rightful place. There lies a scar on the side of Dunagiri where Hanumana sliced off a big chunk of mythological real estate, a scar which “bleeds” in the afternoon sun. 8/17  Himalayan Herbs in Sri Lanka Exotic alpine Himalayan species are found suddenly amidst tropical Sri Lankan vegetation, the legacy of Hanuman’s heroic voyage carrying a mountain with life-restoring herbs called Sanjeevani. 9/17  Ashok Vatika, Sri Lanka It was the location where Mata Sita was held captive by Ravana after her abduction, because she refused to stay in Ravana's palace, and preferred to stay under the Ashoka tree, hence the name. Much of the Ashoka Vatika was destroyed by Hanuman ji, when he first visited Lanka, searching for Mata Sita. Its present location is believed to be the Hakgala Botanical Garden, the area is known as Seetha Eliya. 10/18  Existence of Lepakshi, Andhra Pradesh When Mata Sita was abducted by Ravana, they bumped into Jatayu, a demi-god in vulture form, who tried his best to stop Ravana. Lepakshi, in Andhra Pradesh, is said to be the place where Jatayu fell down. Shree Ram, accompanied by Hanuman ji and Laxman ji met the dying Jatayu. Shree Ram helped him to attain moksha by uttering the words "Le Pakshi", which is Telugu for "Rise, bird". There's also a large footprint in that area which is said to be that of Hanumana's.  11/17  Four-tusked elephants Sundar Kanda [4.27.12] states that Hanuman ji, on entering Lanka, sees Four-Tusked elephants guarding the palaces of Ravana. These elephants were tall and imposing and had been trained to protect Lanka from invaders. Well, fossil remains show that there were many steps in the evolution of the 'Modern Elephant' and there did exist four-tusked ancestors of elephants in various shapes and sizes such as Trilophodon, Tetralophodon, Gomphotherium etc around 20 million years ago! 12/17  Existence of Konda Kattu Gala, Ishtreepura This was one of the places to which King Ravana shifted Mata Sita as a precautionary measure which he was forced to take by Lord Hanuman's advent. There are lots of intruding tunnels and caves in this area. This seems to be a part of a great ingenious network of paths, which is interconnected to all the major areas of King Ravana's city. 13/17  Ravana’s palace These tunnels prove beyond doubt the architectural brilliance of King Ravana. These tunnels served as a quick means of transport through the hills and also as a secret passage and networked all the important cities, airports and dairy farms. A close look at these tunnels indicates that they are man-made and not natural formations. This Buddhist shrine at Kalutara was where once King Ravana's palace and a tunnel existed there. 14/17  Kalaniya After King Ravana’s death, Vibhishana was coronated as The King of Lanka by Lakshmana ji at Kelaniya. There are murals enshrined outside the Buddhist temple depicting the crowning of Vibhishana. The Kelani River is mentioned in the Valmiki Ramayana and Vibhishana’s palace was said to be on the banks of this river. 15/17  Proof of Lord Hanuman setting fire to Ravana’s kingdom The color of the soil of the ancient battlefield is still red today, and is still surrounded by lighter colored earth. One of the airports of Ravana, torched by Hanuman ji when he came looking for Mata Sita, still has a scorched-earth look. A patch of darker soil surrounded by brown earth. 16/17  Divurumpola, Sri Lanka After Shree Ram rescued Mata Sita from Lanka, he made her go through Agni Pariksha to test her purity. The place where this is said to have happened is Divurumpola in Sri Lanka. There is a tree in that exact spot and even today, local disputes are settled through debates and discussions under that tree. 17/17  Ramalingam Since Shree Rama felt guilty of killing a Brahmin (Brahmahasthi Dosham), he decided to take penance at Munneswaram, 80 km from present Colombo. This is the place where lord Rama prayed to lord Shiva and lord Shiva answered his prayer by asking him to install four lingams. Out of this four, one of the linga was made of sand by Mata sita and other brought by lord hanuman from Kailash Mountain. Lingams at Rameshwaram and Manavari temple was built by lord Rama himself and so, is known as Ramlingam. Now, let’s move to the mahabharata.  The Mahabharata: History or Fiction? If there be a word for the most incredible tale ever told – then it is the story of the Mahabharat. There is a great debate about whether there is any historical accuracy in the story of Mahabharata. This narrative is so remarkable that it has made numerous people speculate - ‘Did it really happen? Let’s find some proofs that indicate mahabharat is our itihas. 1/20   Decoding the language It has been written in the epic from time to time that Mahabharat is a "itihas" which exclusively means "thus occured". The words "Puraan" and "Itihas" were specifically coined by the ancient people to categorize the "ancient" and "recent" events. Both the words denote history that has occurred at different times. If the intentions of the writer were to write a poem or a work of fiction, he would have stated it to be a "mahakavya" or "katha".  2/20 Records of the Bharat-Dynasty It is mentioned in Aadiparva, Adhyaya 62 that the records of the Bharat-Dynasty are recorded in the Mahabharata. A number of dynasties with their long lineage of kings (more than 50 from Manu) have been presented in the work. If it were just fiction, 4-5 kings would have sufficed to build the story on. 3/20  Details of Kaliguga Read the description of Kaliyuga as mentioned in Mahabharata. Whatever Shree Krishna said tallies with creepy, mysterious accurateness with modern life as it exists today. And remember - this was written thousands of years ago! Fiction? Unlikely because there are way too many corroborations and tallying circumstances for it to be fiction. 4/20  The city of Dwaraka Marine archaeology has also been utilized in India off the coast of the ancient port city of Dwaraka in Gujarat, uncovering further evidence in support of statements in the Vedic scriptures. An entire submerged city at Dvaraka, the ancient port city of Lord Krishna with its massive fort walls, piers, warfs and jetty has been found in the ocean as described in the Mahabharata and other Vedic literatures. This sanskrit verse from the Mausala Parva 7 verse 40 of the Mahabharata, describes the disappearance of the city of Dvaraka into the sea. "After all the people had set out, the ocean flooded Dvaraka, which still teemed with wealth of every kind. Whatever portion of land was passed over, the ocean immediately flooded over with its waters." 5/20  Ancient cities described in the Mahabharatha More than thirty-five sites in North India have yielded archaeological evidence and have been identified as ancient cities described in the Mahabharatha. Copper utensils, iron, seals, gold & silver ornaments, terracotta discs and painted grey ware pottery have all been found in these sites. Scientific dating of these artifacts corresponds to the non-aryan-invasion model of Indian antiquity. 6/20  Similarity between Ramayana and Mahabharata The dynasties recorded in the Ramayan and the Mahabharat concur without a difference. Even the relations between different kings and their dynasties in both the great "epics" match with each other. If both were mere "epics" written by two entirely different at two different times, why would everything match even upto minor details? Mahabharat is of a later date than the Ramayan. Why would the author of the Mahabharat borrow the same ideas and characters as those of the author of Ramayana? 7/20  Lineage of Shri Krishna The Greek historian Megasthenes has stated that Chandragupta Maurya was the 138 King in the lineage of Shri Krishna. This means that Shri Krishna did exist in the bygone era and that Mahabharat did really occur. 8/20  Present cities from Mahbaharata All places mentioned in Mahabharata are real places, all are identified as real places. For instance, Hastinapur is in UP. Indraprastha is the present day Delhi. Dwarka is located in Gujarat coast. Moreover, Mahabharata cities are not limited to present day India because Mahabharata referred Indian subcontinent as Bharata. For example, Gandhar could be present day Kandhar. 9/20  Astronomical references The Udyoga Parva of Mahabharata narrates that, just before the War, Lord Krishna went to Hastinapur in the month of Kartika on the day when moon was at the asterism Revati. On His way to Hastinapur, Krishna took rest for a day at a place called Brikasthala, and on that day the moon was at the asterism Bharani. The day on which Duryodhana turned down all the efforts of Krishna and made the war inevitable, the moon was resting at the asterism Pushya. 10/20  Bharat Varsh The country is named Bhaarat after the king Bharat (son of Dushyant & Shakuntala). What country would be named after the hero of a novel! 11/20  Hole in the Aryan theory European scholars brought the nomadic Aryan tribes, into India after 1500 BC. How could these Aryans create Sanskrit language, gain so much knowledge and write all these texts before 700 BC? Great Indian thinkers including Lokmanya Tilak, Sri Arbindo, and Dyanand Sarasvati rejected the European theory. 12/20  Mahabharata is written in verses It is ridiculous to say that these texts are fiction, because of its poetic nature. It was a custom to write everything (even Mathematical formulae) in poetic form. 13/20  Unrecorded history factor Maurya, Gupta and Indo-Greek dynasties, are also recorded in our Puraanas. These dynasties are accepted only because they are also recorded by Greek historians. What about the dynasties that existed before the Greek historians? 14/20  Citing Oppenheimer The architect of modern atomic bomb who was in charge of the Manhattan project was asked by a student after the manhattan explosion, “How do you feel after having exploded the first atomic bomb on earth”. Oppenheimer’s reply for the question was, “not first atomic bomb, but first atomic bomb in modern times”. He strongly believed that nukes were used in ancient India. 15/20 Some Unanswered questions What made Oppenheimer believe that it was a nuclear war was the accurate descriptions of the weapons used in the Mahabharata war in the epic which match with that of modern nuclear weapons? How much truth is there in the stories that claim that a region in Kurukshetra still have high level of radio activity? 16/20  The Gregorian Calendar Not a surprise, but surely very interesting to note that the Gregorian Calendar indeed vouches for the Kurukshetra War to have taken place, as it states the beginning of Kali Yuga. Per the Calendar, the event occurred on February 18, 3102 BCE at 2:27:30 AM. Both, the Eastern and Western culture have accepted this date and time to have been the beginning of Kali Yuga and, also the death of Lord Krishna. 17/20  The Underwater Discoveries Among the extensive and deep underwater discoveries were the massive Dwarka city wall, a large door socket and a bastion from the fort wall, natural harbour, two rock-cut slipways of different width and sizes extending from the beach to the intertidal zone and numerous old stone ship anchors were excavated.  The three-headed motif on a sea-conch shell was also found in the excavation and such motif is referred in the scripture Harivamsa is a further proof of the existence of Dwarka city and a direct link to Kurukshetra war. 18/20  Perfect narration of the planetary positions Krishna left Hastinapura with Karna, on the day when the moon was yet to reach the asterism Uttara Phalguni. Karna accompanied Him to some distance to see him off and he then described to the Lord the positions of planets in the sky. He expressed his apprehension that such a planetary configuration stood for a very bad omen: such as large scale loss of life and drenching of blood. Vyasa narrated all these planetary positions in as many as sixteen verses as if someone was describing it after visualizing them in the sky. 19/20   Flying Aircraft & Nuclear War The Indian Epics, especially the MAHABHARATA, pick up the thread of the tale of devastation and destruction. Sanskrit scholars could not comprehend what was being described in the Epics until the dropping of the first atomic bombs on Japan.  There are Authentic Verses from Mahabharata: “Gurkha, flying a swift and powerful vimana (fast aircraft) hurled a single projectile (rocket) charged with the power of the Universe (nuclear device). An incandescent column of smoke and flame, as bright as ten thousand suns, rose with all its splendour.” 20/20  The Ramayana and The Mahabharata doesn’t have a happy ending. If you write a story, then the main character of your story will be shown as superior to everyone and glorified. He will not suffer. Just like movies, The villain dies in the end not hero. But in The Ramayana, Mata Sita the wife of hero suffers and in the last the hero(Shree Rama) dies. If it was a story then the story would have ended after Shree Rama killed Ravana. Shree Rama would returm to Ayodhya and rule the kingdom. Similarly in The Mahabharata, Arjuna forgets his dhanur vidya and can not lift his Gaandeev. Shree Krishna leaves his body and his entire dynasty ends. These were some facts and proofs that indicate that these are not just stories, these are our history. Stop calling them mythological or fictional stories. Thanks for reading! (Images were used for representation purpose only). Pic source: Internet

Let me put it this way.  Do you think that there could have been a flying monkey with the strength to lift a mountain weighing infinite tonnes? Do you think that a man could grow 10 heads after being decapitated? Is there any way that a monkey could fly up to the sun and try to swallow it? If there is any rational scientific explanations for these questions, then I'm all ears. My stand is that Ramayana and Mahabharata are great pieces of literature and should be considered that way.  Valmiki and Vyasa wrote wonderful mythologies which teach great moral values, but in doing so, they used a lot of metaphorical symbolism and and over-the-top imaginative scenarios to make it intriguing. At the same time, they didn't refrain from using real locations, that existed in Southern Asia to make the story more relate-able. The human mind is susceptible to delusion. Since it's been drilled into our minds to believe that a certain thing exists and it's real and it's good for you doesn't mean it is always necessarily true.  If it were true, we should be getting more plausible evidence of this. If Mahabharata is actually true, then millions of lives were lost in that war, that means certainly we should have found some form of evidence of a millions of humans and animals losing their lives in Kurukshetra. Even if most of the human corpses were cremated, there still must be thousands of animal corpses that were unaccounted for, whose fossils should have been found. For heaven's sake, if we can find millions of years old fossils of a T-Rex, can't we find some evidence for a great battle that happened relatively, much much later than the extinction of the Dinosaurs?

Yes, they are certainly based on true events. However, the exact historical dates are unknown. Many might argue them to be mythologies but there are some concrete reasons to believe them. One of the reasons is, the places described in Ramayana & Mahabharata still exist. For example, Ayodhya, Palk Strait, Sri Lanka, Mathura, Vrindavan, and so on. In Kurukshektra, that is in Haryana, where the battle of Mahabharata took place, still remains of metals, shaped as swords, clubs etc. are found. The historical ruins that are found are according to exact descriptions and definitions. Still, these accounts seems to be beyond reality. This is particularly because of the type of language used. Sometimes, they does not seem to make any sense. Let me give some reasons one finds hard to believe in them and their reasons too. :: At present times, our perceptions about words and descriptions has changed as time passed. There were technologies that exist in that time which might be beyond our imagination. We should take into account that, it was history and many unknown things existed at that time as the environment was utterly different and so were the peoples. It was just different time in a different society. It is sometimes bizarre for us to imagine ourselves in Victorian age. How can we imagine how would be the ages of Ramayana and Mahabharata. Also, Ramayana was earlier that Mahabharata. :: Another, aspect is the translation and descriptions by different persons in different point of time. We only know that, these epics were written by the saint Vyed Vyas in Sanskrit. But the original version is lost! What we have now are just the interpretations of many subsequent versions. :: Chronology: The time described in Ramayana and Mahabharata is based on Vedic descriptions. It is said that Mahabharata happened in Dwapar Yug, that existed for around 50,00, 000 years before 5000 years! And Ramayana is an account of what happened before Dwapar Yug! So, if we match this up with the western chronology of Prehistoric ages, like palaeolithic age, Mesolithic age, we can reach nowhere. For this, we should look closely to the prehistoric time sequences. There are huge gaps of thousands of years in the so called stone ages, that are unaccounted. Moreover, still relics and remains are discovered time to time that puts archaeologist to a complete jeopardy. The dates just do not match up! We cannot clam that the Vedic chronology is accurate, because we are even not sure of some Sanskrit words, there is a great possibility of misinterpretations. However, we also cannot believe the chronology of prehistoric stone ages. It is disappointing to know still there are people who believe Mahabharata is a story and not as a history. It would be interesting if these ‘intellectuals’ does not think Iliad and Odyssey were fairy tales and try to find logic behind Troy, Achilles and Hector. There are concrete historical evidences about Mahabharata and there are no exaggerations in any account. The anomalies occur only because of difference in understanding separate writings and inscriptions throughout history. Map of India in the Age of the Mahabharata There are tonnes of reliable material even on internet. The actual controversy is on the exact period when the war happened. Chronological timelines mentioned in scriptures does not match because they follow different calendars. What we follow now as 2017 is per Gregorian Calendar. There are dozens of such calendars throughout the world that follows unique timelines. In India itself there are several calendars following contrasting dates. About those absurdity of mythical powers, let me give an example. Lachit Borphukon was the great Ahom general who did not let Mughals enter Assam. He defeated the Mughal Army in the famous Battle of Saraighat in 1671. I was rather surprised looking at his personal sword preserved at Guwahati Museum. It is 12 feet long weighting 18 Kilos! Can you imagine someone fighting today with a 12 feet long sword weighting 18 Kilos in a face to face battle? Even a barely 350 years old history and its personalities appear as something hard to believe. What about a history that is more than 6000 years old? The truth is: Only fools assume darkness as void.

There’s an old joke that if civilization were to be wiped out, and if the new species discovered JRR Tolkien’s Lord of the Rings they would believe it to be the past’s religion just because the books are so immaculately crafted.  That’s what most religious scriptures are fictional books, you don’t want to learn what happened then or who did it, it is not history. Period. What a reader should take away from them are the profound lessons that a good reader can take away from any good book. Religious fanatics are like kids high on sugar, claiming their books are the best. Their author’s the one telling the truth, but none of them are true.  Now. I haven’t read either of the books. Scratch that, I haven’t read any religious scripture. All my knowledge about them stems from a handful of animated movies and that should tell you enough I’m no authority on this matter. But even if 10% of the movie is true to the source material that should tell you none of it was true. But the lessons of duty, honesty, truthfulness, honor will be ever relevant. Try and understand this beautiful extract from Rami Sivan’s answer to the same question. Please try to understand - the ancient Hindus were never interested in HISTORY, they were interested in the quality of human character and the content and evolution of consciousness and modeling ideal behavior. These epics are not to be mined for historical data - which may or may not be there - history is HIS STORY and not relevant to us - here and now - what is important for us in MY STORY - how do these Epics help you to orient yourself in this crazy world, here and now! What lessons can be learned and what is the implication for adaptive action[1]!  Cheers. And I’ll probably not be replying to the comments to this question, unless, of course, there’s a joke involved. Footnotes[1] Rami Sivan's answer to Are Ramayan and Mahabharata real?

I subscribe to the folklorists' view, so my answer is probably not. Thanks for the A2A, Prathamesh Deshpande. Edit: It's been a while since I wrote that, and now I am more certain. The epics are 100% fictional. How do I conclude this? Let's start by talking about something more recent - say, Captain America. Just bear with me, this will be good. Captain America was a comic book superhero created by Joe Simon and Jack Kirby, who were both Jewish. In fact, they had created the Captain America comics before the USA officially entered WWII through the Pacific theatre. Yet the very first issue showed Cap socking Hitler on the Jaw. Notice some facts here: The World War II was a real multinational conflict fought on at least two different theatres/frontsThe USA entered said conflict, and was part of the alliance that emerged victoriousThe results of the Manhattan Project, and many such scientific and technological breakthroughs were indeed crucial in deciding the outcome of the war Much of this research was indeed done by scientists who had started fleeing Europe as far back as the 1920'sNow question: Given these facts, would anyone consider the Captain America franchise as "real"? Would anyone make a claim that Captain America was historical in nature? No. You can't learn history from Captain America, because it is not historical in nature. And yet the identical claim is being made for the Mahabharata, and to some extent, the Ramayana. Real, historical wars always have been popular subjects of fictional stories. Goodreads lists 740 such works related to World War II alone.  And then there's the talk of evidence. We have to understand that we are trying to verify the truth of the narrative here, not the setting. The only way to verify a narrative is to: Strip the narrative of any poetic license, hyperbole etc.Find independent sources which document the narrativeFind artifacts that can be unambiguously traced back to the events of the narrativeWe don't have any such evidence for the epics at all. Yes both are real, but it depends on you that how you see it. 1. Mahabharata: History or Fiction?  If there be a word for the most incredible tale ever told – then it is the story of the Mahabharat. There is a great debate about whether there is any historical accuracy in the story of Mahabharata. This narrative is so remarkable that it has made numerous people speculate - ‘Did it really happen? Let’s find some answers… 2. Decoding the language  It has been written in the epic from time to time that Mahabharat is a "itihas" which exclusively means "thus occured". The words "Puraan" and "Itihas" were specifically coined by the ancient people to categorize the "ancient" and "recent" events. Both the words denote history that has occurred at different times. If the intentions of the writer were to write a poem or a work of fiction, he would have stated it to be a "mahakavya" or "katha". 3. Records of the Bharat-Dynasty  It is mentioned in Aadiparva, Adhyaya 62 that the records of the Bharat-Dynasty are recorded in the Mahabharata. A number of dynasties with their long lineage of kings (more than 50 from Manu) have been presented in the work. If it were just fiction, 4-5 kings would have sufficed to build the story on. 4. Details of Kaliguga  Read the description of Kaliyuga as mentioned in Mahabharata. Whatever Krishna said tallies with creepy, mysterious accurateness with modern life as it exists today. And remember - this was written thousands of years ago! Fiction? Unlikely because there are way too many corroborations and tallying circumstances for it to be fiction. 5. The city of Dwaraka  Marine archaeology has also been utilized in India off the coast of the ancient port city of Dwaraka in Gujarat, uncovering further evidence in support of statements in the Vedic scriptures. An entire submerged city at Dvaraka, the ancient port city of Lord Krishna with its massive fort walls, piers, warfs and jetty has been found in the ocean as described in the Mahabharata and other Vedic literatures. 6. The unfortunate fate of Dwaraka  This sanskrit verse from the Mausala Parva 7 verse 40 of the Mahabharata, describes the disappearance of the city of Dvaraka into the sea. "After all the people had set out, the ocean flooded Dvaraka, which still teemed with wealth of every kind. Whatever portion of land was passed over, the ocean immediately flooded over with its waters." 7. Ancient cities described in the Mahabharatha  More than thirty-five sites in North India have yielded archaeological evidence and have been identified as ancient cities described in the Mahabharatha. Copper utensils, iron, seals, gold & silver ornaments, terracotta discs and painted grey ware pottery have all been found in these sites. Scientific dating of these artifacts corresponds to the non-aryan-invasion model of Indian antiquity. 8. Similarity between Ramayana and Mahabharata  The dynasties recorded in the Ramayan and the Mahabharat concur without a difference. Even the relations between different kings and their dynasties in both the great "epics" match with each other. If both were mere "epics" written by two entirely different at two different times, why would everything match even upto minor details? Mahabharat is of a later date than the Ramayan. Why would the author of the Mahabharat borrow the same ideas and characters as those of the author of Ramayana? 9. Lineage of Shri Krishna  The Greek historian Megasthenes has stated that Chandragupta Maurya was the 138 King in the lineage of Shri Krishna. This means that Shri Krishna did exist in the bygone era and that Mahabharat did really occur. 10. Present cities from Mahbaharata  All places mentioned in Mahabharata are real places, all are identified as real places. For instance, Hastinapur is in UP. Indraprastha is the present day Delhi. Dwarka is located in Gujarat coast. Moreover, Mahabharata cities are not limited to present day India because Mahabharata referred Indian subcontinent as Bharata. For example, Gandhar could be present day Kandhar. 11. Astronomical references  The Udyoga Parva of Mahabharata narrates that, just before the War, Lord Krishna went to Hastinapur in the month of Kartika on the day when moon was at the asterism Revati. On His way to Hastinapur, Krishna took rest for a day at a place called Brikasthala, and on that day the moon was at the asterism Bharani. The day on which Duryodhana turned down all the efforts of Krishna and made the war inevitable, the moon was resting at the asterism Pushya. 12. Perfect narration of the planetary positions  Krishna left Hastinapura with Karna, on the day when the moon was yet to reach the asterism Uttara Phalguni. Karna accompanied Him to some distance to see Him off and he then described to the Lord the positions of planets in the sky and expressed his apprehension that such a planetary configuration stood for very bad omen: such as large scale loss of life and drenching of blood. Vyasa narrated all these planetary positions in as many as sixteen verses as if someone was describing it after visualizing them in the sky. 13. Bharat Varsh  The country is named Bhaarat after the king Bharat (son of Dushyant & Shakuntala). What country would be named after the hero of a novel! 14. Hole in the Aryan theory  European scholars brought the nomadic Aryan tribes, into India after 1500 BC. How could these Aryans create Sanskrit language, gain so much knowledge and write all these texts before 700 BC? Great Indian thinkers including Lokmanya Tilak, Sri Arbindo, and Dyanand Sarasvati rejected the European theory. 15. Mahabharata is written in verses  It is ridiculous to say that these texts are fiction, because of its poetic nature. It was a custom to write everything (even Mathematical formulae) in poetic form. 16. Unrecorded history factor  Maurya, Gupta and Indo-Greek dynasties, are also recorded in our Puraanas. These dynasties are accepted only because they are also recorded by Greek historians. What about the dynasties that existed before the Greek historians? 17. Flying Aircraft & Nuclear War  The Indian Epics, especially the MAHABHARATA, pick up the thread of the tale of devastation and destruction. Sanskrit scholars could not comprehend what was being described in the Epics until the dropping of the first atomic bombs on Japan. There are Authentic Verses from Mahabharata: “Gurkha, flying a swift and powerful vimana (fast aircraft) hurled a single projectile (rocket) charged with the power of the Universe (nuclear device). An incandescent column of smoke and flame, as bright as ten thousand suns, rose with all its splendor.” 18. Citing Oppenheimer  The architect of modern atomic bomb who was in charge of the Manhattan project was asked by a student after the manhattan explosion, “How do you feel after having exploded the first atomic bomb on earth”. Oppenheimer’s reply for the question was, “not first atomic bomb, but first atomic bomb in modern times”. He strongly believed that nukes were used in ancient India. 19. Some Unanswered questions  What made Oppenheimer believe that it was a nuclear war was the accurate descriptions of the weapons used in the Mahabharata war in the epic which match with that of modern nuclear weapons? How much truth is there in the stories that claim that a region in Kurukshetra still have high level of radio activity?

The Mahabharata in 18 volumes is an ENCYCLOPEDIA - it contains everything — philosophy, theology, ethics, history, animal husbandry, astrology, Ayur Veda, architecture, domestic science, politics, myths, legends, humour, romance, war, etc. etc. etc. In fact the Mahabharata itself says that there is nothing in the human world which is not found in it. I believe that both the Mahabharata and Ramayana were based on real events, stylized by later poets. The Ramayana was much more stylized than the Mahabharata. I’ve answered several questions on Quora about the Mahabharata analyzing different questions from the standpoint that at its kernel, the Mahabharata is a real, historical story without any magic and supernatural elements. Over time, this has attracted its fair share of controversy, and various people on Quora have challenged my position as being unfair to Hinduism by disbelieving in it. Treating Krishna as a human being (rather than a God) especially attracts many negative comments. But this word, ‘belief’. What does it mean in Hindu philosophy? Throughout the Gita, Krishna says one must have shraddha if one is to benefit from the scriptures - the word translates to ‘faith’. When analyzing whether these epics are ‘real’, the real question we should ask ourselves is, is it possible to be a good Hindu - a Hindu with shraddha - while taking a non-supernatural position on the epics. Let’s look at three books, in increasing order of ‘un-believability’ - the Gita, the Mahabharata, and the Ramayana. The Gita is almost completely devoid of supernatural elements, and in fact, many teachers of the Gita (my Guru included) teach it as a philosophical work. There are many lineages of Gurus who do the same. In fact, one great piece of advice I received when I began the study of the Gita was this: if there is any element of your understanding of Hindu scriptures which contradicts science and scientific observation, you must go back and change your interpretation of the scriptures — because the scriptures are a real, factual description of the Universe and can withstand scientific scrutiny. The Mahabharata is not a scripture in the way the Gita is. The puranas and itihasas do not hold the same status which is granted to the Vedas and the Upanishads. Even in the Vedas and Upanishads, there are the central teachings and there are the peripheral stories that are used as a vehicle to convey those teachings. So it is possible to believe in the Gita without believing that Lord Krishna stopped time in the middle of the battlefield and recited the verses to Arjuna. There is no shraddha problem with the Gita. Unfortunately, this cannot be said of the Mahabharata, which had layers and layers of interpolation on top of a core historical text. It is not possible to reconcile the possibility of supernatural, magical occurrences that happened 3000 or 5000 years ago, with the real archeological evidence from the Indus Valley Civilization, Egypt, China, and other contemporary historical events. Even some basic facts do not tally. We know for instance, using radiocarbon dating, that the iron age in India started around 1800BC. Yet there are references to iron in the Mahabharata - kings fight with swords, for instance Drona’s head is cut off by Dhrishtadyumna using an iron sword. The logical conclusion to this is that (a) either the Mahabharata happened post the Iron Age, or (b) swords (and other iron artifacts) were a later interpolation to the Mahabharata, or (c) it was written (as a complete work of fiction) after that period. In all instances of this kind of discrepancy, I find the most consistent approach is option (b). Unlike the Ramayana, it doesn’t take a lot of compromising to make the Mahabharata internally consistent and non-supernatural at the same time. The Critical Edition is a remarkably logical, factual and sane version of the Mahabharata, in which the supernatural episodes account for a small percentage of the total work. It is only the Amar Chitra Katha and BR Chopra versions of the Mahabharata that reinforce this stereotype of fights with magical weapons and divine interventions. For the sake of completeness, I also want to explain why I do not subscribe to (a) and (c). As we progress forward in history - for example, post the Iron Age, we see more and more archeological artifacts from Indian history, in the form of buildings, excavations, pottery, and references to India in other civilizations. The later we date the Mahabharata (and therefore the more advanced technology we are willing to accept), the less consistent it becomes with all of this historical record. I do not subscribe to (c) partly because of factual reasons and partly because of Shraddha. As long as it is consistent with science, there is no reason to disbelieve the Mahabharata. The Mahabharata is such a detailed work, with many vast areas that are totally unconnected with the main story, that if it was a fictional work, it would not make narrative sense. In his translation of the Critical Edition, Bibek Debroy gives the example of the description of Kripi, the wife of Drona. There is no earthly reason why this should be included in a story about a war, but there it is. Debroy cites hundreds of such extraneous details and descriptions as evidence that they described real events, and I agree with him. There is a particular kind of Hindu revivalist today who denies all three options (a), (b) and (c). According to this kind of person, the Mahabharata happened in all its detail, without any compromise, with all the supernatural elements and stories. Unfortunately, the only way that this could have happened is in a parallel universe with no Indus Valley and no historical evidence. It could only have happened in some other devaloka, whose history is hidden to our archeologists. For me, given my own spiritual education so far, it is this attitude of other-worldliness that demonstrates a lack of Shraddha. The beauty of Hindu philosophy is that it is immediate - relevant - applicable to our here and now. It has the most beautiful explanations of the human condition, and the most wonderful manual of how to live in this complicated, unpredictable world. I have found that many people who believe in the ‘strong’ version of the epics (i.e. magic, supernatural, etc.) are therefore less convinced about the need to apply the teachings of the scriptures to the world around them. These are the people who believe Ganga resides in Siva’s top-knot, and at the same time don’t think twice about building polluting industries on the Ganga’s banks. True Shraddha means realizing that the divine Ganga of the scriptures is the same Ganga that flows through the enormity of our Northern plains; and it means living life according to the philosophy of the scriptures. These are the people who believe that Shiva grafted his own son’s body on an elephant’s head - but destroy the habitat of thousands of elephants for a half percent increase in GDP. The scriptures are real. And our belief in them elevates us and enlightens us - IF we choose to believe that they apply to our real lives here and now, and do not just deal with some idealized devaloka somewhere else.

It is true that we do not have official historical records to prove that Ramayana or Mahabharatha actually happened. But in my opinion, that should not be a reason to reject the possibility that these might have actually happened. Unfortunately, our official history does not have a clue about the kings,kingdoms and wars that happened before 6th Century BC. Earliest known king in India's official history is Bimbisara of Magadha who ruled between 558 to 491 BC. But clearly, he was not the first king as the historical records describe about Bimbisara avenging the death of his father who was also a king, and so on. The researchers don't know the names of the rulers who ruled during the Vedic period, and the pre-Vedic period (Indus valley civilization). It is possible that some of the vital historical records could have been lost when the grand libraries of Nalanda and Taxila were destroyed by the invaders. Also, the “Indus script” found in various artifacts from Mohanjo-daro, Harappa, Lothal etc. are not deciphered yet. If researchers find a way to interpret their meaning, I believe that will also help in uncovering our hidden history. The truth of Ramayana and Mahabharatha lies dormant inside a thick blanket of mystery that surrounds our ancient history. In my opinion there is a high chance that the events in Ramayana and Mahabharatha could have happened. If we eliminate the supernatural aspects from these stories, that could point to some real events happened during those times. These events might have inspired Valmiki and Vyasa to pen down Ramayana and Mahabharatha respectively. We should remember that we thought of Iliad, Homer's epic, to be a fiction, until archaeologists dug up the remnants of ancient city of Troy in present day Turkey. Let us hope that one day our historians and archaeologists will be able to solve this mystery!

Many of us seem to believe that all the ancient Indian literature say, before 1000 BC is not based on any real events but purely based on human imagination. If so, there is no way to know anything about the ancient ways of life, how societies have evolved over time. Unfortunately, there were no conscious efforts at recording history for future generations in ancient times, especially when there was no script. People just recollect certain important incidents happened and pass on to others, in their own style. The Vedas, for example are not without historical points. Although nothing is proved beyond doubt, events such as the Battle of Ten Kings, the existence of Saraswati river, the glories of ancient tribes are all there for discerning researchers. Other than these stories and epics, there are no authentic base for ancient history. We are fortunate to have certain ancient texts and treatises like Vedas, Puranas and Itihasas, that can help us to get some idea of how people lived and what are the social norms, what are the laws and customs and so on. Although everything may not have solid proof, there has always been scope for debate as to what is fact and what is imagination. Even for that matter, even the modern recorded history is subject to different interpretations. Some even said that history is biased towards the victorious. Can anybody tell us exactly why and how the partition of our country into India and Pakistan took place? There are different versions, and different narrations. Indians have one version, Pakistanis have another version, British have some other version, Congress party have some other version, BJP has some other version. Similarly, if you ask someone to narrate the history of Moghul dynasty, he will give his own version. As for the proofs, proofs such as the archeological findings, they keep on changing with new findings. It is a continuous process. The Kurukshetra battle may be one such incident. People who lived at that time might be knowing how the battle was fought what was the background etc. But as the story passes through generations, intermingled with the creative imaginations of the story tellers over the ages. In the absence of any authentic history, we do depend upon the stories and literature of the age for knowing the history, cultural ethos, and ways of life. In ancient ages, history was not separately recorded. Important events are remembered, passed on from generation to generation.

I have read both, and many parts of them more than once. I worship Krishna and Rama and have no trouble believing them both to be real accounts of real people involved in real events. This is not because I am a great scholar and have read the research papers of Western academics, nor because I have sifted through archeological evidence or made calculations based on the eclipses and planetary positions described in the books. Nor am I botanist who can confirm that the descriptions of flora and fauna and the geographical locations are precise. I haven’t swum underwater off Gujarat searching for the ruins of Dwarka. I’m pretty lazy when it comes to this sort of investigation. I have read accounts of all these with interest and noted that they confirm my acceptance of them as real, but this all came after I accepted them as real. That decision was very quick and simple. Srila Prabhupada said they were real, and I believe everything he says. Growing up I never heard of Srila Prabhupada nor of Mahabharata and Ramayana. I heard a bit about Jesus and how the universe appeared and formed itself and humans are just another kind of ape. It wasn’t great, but there you are, that’s how it is. One thing became clear though as I entered my late teens, there are a lot of things going on that we don't know much about. Modern science has discovered some interesting things, but it hasn’t answered many interesting questions yet, and the most interesting ones, well to be blunt, it can’t answer them at all. Now, if a person accepts Mahabharat and Ramayana as real there’s a lot of fascinating information in them. They throw doors wide open to a whole different way of looking at things and deciding what to do in life. They lead to recognizing that much of what we have learnt is not necessarily true, but a ‘best guess’ from limited data. The conclusions in these books are very profound, but not everyone wants to be bothered with profound conclusions. Some would rather keep things simple. Eat, work, eat, sex, sleep. repeat till no longer possible. Be a good person. (You get to decide what’s good). But some of us dare to dream that there is more going on than just a ball of matter spinning in orbit, hurtling through space with nothing guiding it. That we are not just animated chemicals that appear to be alive for a while till our heart stops and all life disappears, like a fountain when the pump is switched off. We are free to accept Mahabharat and Ramayana as real because we dare to say “I don’t believe you” to those telling us we are apes and we have to invent some purpose for staying alive for however long we can stay alive. We don’t sift through these books, looking for some gems of wisdom which we pick out while ignoring the bits that don’t appeal. We don’t regard them simply as stories to showcase ethical life for humans, that they are symbolically portraying the inner struggles of morality that introspective people wrestle with by creating a story out of thin air, like a modern Hollywood/Bollywood/Tollywood production. For us every character is real, every event happened, the messages are still there, they are deliberately arranged like that because the personalities involved in the stories are the scriptwriters for the universe, and the inhabitants of the universe are the cast. This is a Cosmicollywood production, not a cartoon, and for us, the show is magnificent because it’s all real.

Whether or not the Mahabharata actually happened is a difficult thing to say. One can at best make a guess. Leaving aside the archeological evidence, one can take astronomical route. Many astronomical signs are present in the epic itself, notably in the Udyogaparva and Bhishmaparva. These astronomical events may be taken as basis for a computer aided search by simulating the past sky. I am particularly influenced by the works of Narahari Achar. First of all, its generally accepted that the war took place at the transition between Dwapara and Kaliyuga, around 3000 BCE. Out of many signs mentioned in the epic, the following planetary configurations are common in both (and more important towards establishing a unique date) of the Parvas mentioned above:1)  conjunction of Sani (Saturn) with Rohini (Aldebaran)2)  retrograde motion of Angaraka (Mars) just before reaching Jyestha (Antares)3)  a lunar eclipse on the kartika purnima (that is near Pleiades),followed by4)  a solar eclipse at jyestha.Narahari Achar then talks of the method as follows(using a planetarium software): A search is made for the years in which there is a conjunction of Saturn (Sani) with Aldebaran (Rohini) between 3500 BCE and 500 CE. As Saturn takes an average of 29.5 years to go around the sun once, the event also repeats with the same period. There are 137 such conjunctions during the interval specified above. A search is then made for those years from among these 137 dates when Mars (Angaraka) is retrograde before reaching Antares (Jyestha). Since the retrograde motion of Mars repeats with the same period as its synodic period, a spread of two years on either side of each of the dates was considered in the search. The search reduced the set to just seventeen: 3271 BCE, 3067 BCE, 2830 BCE,  2625 BCE, 2388 BCE, 2183 BCE, 1946 BCE, 1741 BCE, 1503 BCE, 1299 BCE, 1061 BCE, 857 BCE, 620 BCE, 415 BCE, 28 CE, 233 CE and 470 CE, when Saturn was near Aldebaran and Mars executed a retrograde motion before reaching Antares. A search is then made for those years in whichthere is a lunar eclipse near Pleiades (i.e., on the Kartika Purnima). This reduces the set to just two, 3067 BCE and 2183 BCE. It turns out that in both of these years the lunar eclipse is followed by a solar eclipse at Jyestha. A sequence of ‘two eclipses within a period of 13 days’ also occurs in the two eclipse seasons. When one considers the fact that Bhisma passed away on the Magha Sukla astami, after the occurrence of winter solstice, a unique date results, for the winter solstice in January 13, 3066 BCE occurred on Suklapancami, where as the winter solstice in 2182 BCE occurred on Krishnachaturthi. Thus a unique date of 3067 BCE for the date of the war emerges.Here is the author's sky map on 22nd Nov 3067 BCE showing the conjunction of Saturn and Aldebaran  Also here is a sky map of the same day (but possibly of a different time), I got from Stellarium (a planetarium software) looking in the West direction:   Even if these indications does not necessarily means that Mahabharata actually took place, they still give the state-of-art knowledge of astronomy at that time (or at least the time of the storyline settings). Further this particular year is consistent with many other Vedic sources as well as the Buddhist literature. What I have talked about is essentially a dating of the events, but then why should such consistent astronomical evidence would be present unless things have actually occurred?

From my answer: How correct am I in believing that (Hindu) mythology is actually just philosophical fiction? If so, is it logical to worship it? The Ramayan and The Mahabharat a myth? Even the most vociferous opponent of our mythology - Romila Thapar - does not argue that they are based on fact. There are way too many detailed descriptions of topography, kingdoms and lineages, corroborative mentions in other contemporary sources, astronomical events, geographical descriptions and peoples, number of participating characters for these to be mythical or fictional in nature. The cross-referenced mentions in the Vedas and other holy books pretty much rules that out. The detailed and accurate desrciptions of the land and the kingdoms also have corroborative evidences. The timeline - which was thought impossible until now, as the first settlements in India were thought to be from 2000 BC or so - are also now within acceptable paramters, given that it has now been proven that India was settled with town dwellers as far back as 7300BC.  The point is that first of all, the Hindu books are simply far too detailed for them to be fictional; there are way too many detailed descriptions of real places and people; there are way too many corroborative mentions in other texts - Upanishads, Vedas, Greek mentions etc; there are way too many complexities and characters; there are way too many precise descriptions of events; there are way too many uncannily accurate descriptions of geography and topography spread over 3000 kilometres for them to be entirely fictional. It beggars belief that anyone can create such a massively complex, detailed and vivid descriptions that are so bloody accurate. The hindu books in fact even give a chronology of kings extending 150 generations; this cant all be fiction - esp as we know that a few in the lists are real It is a critical mistake to assume that we know all; only 10 years ago, Saraswati was thought mythical. Surprise, surprise: it was found p-r-e-c-i-s-e-l-y where our so-called fictional books said it would be found. Similarly, the mythical Dwarka. Again, surprise, surprise, we found a city in Gujarat almost precisely tallying with descriptions of Dwarka.  Read the description of Kalyug as written in our books... it tallies with scary, uncanny accuracy with modern life as it exists today. And remember - this written thousands of years ago! Fiction? Unlikely, mate There are w-a-a-a-a-y too many corroborations and tallying circumstances for it to be fiction.  And, if we accept the timeline as accurate - 5000 - 3000 BC, then things begin to click into place. First of all, the evidence of the Saraswati River gives a powerful proof: it is now a known scientific fact that it dried up around 1900 BC, with reduced flows from around 3000-2500BC. The Mahabharat makes specific mention of the Saraswati as a grand and mighty river. It can only have taken place before 2500BC. Furthermore, each and every site stated in the Mahabharat is now known to be true, including Indraprastha. And finding corroborative archeological evidence from so long back is going to be damn tough. And the clincher: by that yardstick adopted, nearly 90 % of history will be myth. Even Ashok was considered mythical until proof was found - his name only occurred in a few books of those times.  Furthermore, the degree of worship and faith in them is way beyond belief; especially considering that it is an essentially non-violent practice with no dogmas and no official heads of religion. It beggard belief that something grounded in fiction can have such a wide and blind following given that it is a non-aggressive religion. The footprint extended is way too large for it to be based on fiction.  You may reject the above argument; that is your prerogative. As regards archeological proof - there is precious little except Dwarka. But there is the evidence of the Saraswati and Dwarka, And as regards antiquity of Krishna and Ram etc; the books themselves are the only proofs - not just the main books - but the other corroborative books as well.  Just remember: 20 years ago, both Saraswati and Dwarka were mythical; The Indus Saraswati was thought to be the Indus civilization from 2000 BC (now thought to be 7000+ BC). Now that you have proof, more and more people are dropping "mythical" term with reference to both.

To answer this first let's start from the question that what exactly are the Ramayana and Mahabharat? They are epics from the Puranas. What are the Puranas? These are tales or stories (a collection of 108 of them ) which were written 2000 years ago to embody the learnings of the vedas which in turn were oral teachings of another 2000 years back. So in a summary the Mahabharat, the Ramayana and many other such epics were actually a way of communicating the rich knowledge of the vedas in a format which was non oral and more importantly could be understood and propagated by the common man. Now coming to the original question of whether these stories were true. In my view they were partially true given the historical places depicted in both epics are very accurate. Also a lot of the astronomical evidences suggested in Mahabharata have been found to have solid ground. Probably there was a king whose wife was abducted and he fought a war to bring her back. But did the villain have a flying chariot? Probably no. Maybe there was a war fought between cousins to inherit the greatest kingdom of the times, but did Gandhari mother 100 children? Probably no again. So u see the gist is that what's important isn't the authenticity of the story but what you learn from it. The Puranas were written to make people understand their responsibilities to a Grihasth jeewan, (a householders life) and in that respect both the epics throw ample light on the subject. I frankly don't believe any one individual can actually imbibe every learning from even one of the epics, forget the other 107 purani stories. Even today when we have discussions on Mahabharata we talk of the altruistic nature of Karna or the arrogance of a Duryodhan, guess the Puranas are still doing their job 2000 years later :-)

I don't want to answer this question directly, but would like to add a perspective. Why does it matter whether Mahabharata happened or not. Why do we want to know? What human purpose does it solve? None, according to me.  Let's ask a different questions - Is Mahabharata true? To this, my answer is yes.  In ancient Indian culture, the idea of "truth" is not subject to "historicity". It is related to sincerity of the narrator and vividness of the content. Mahabharata is a beautifully complex epic poem telling diverse tales, interwoven as dialogues within dialogues, adding up to a hundred thousand verses. Tradition also says that only the twenty-four thousand of these verses were written by the original author. The remaining were added by sages and bards while they roamed the countryside singing the tales of Mahabharata. So our wise ancestors passed on, added, altered, and kept alive the tale which became so big - that it, in a way characterizes our civilization's values. This alive tradition made it so vivid, that everyone can find a character to relate to - or a situation to learn from - or a song to cry to. The main priority of the singers of Mahabharata, was to pass on the human learning - not to be historically accurate. And we should accept it as such, and judge the truthfulness of it by the truthfulness of its characters, situations and stories. This truth is much more profound, and useful, and valuable than the lame historicity of events. Before the British came to India, mythology was the primary means of passing the knowledge of our ancestors. "History" as we know it today was useless and hence in some ways frowned upon. British with their then narrow and barbaric mindset imposed this singular view that History is the ONLY way of knowing the past. This was primarily because they had a long tradition of writing histories glorifying their past rulers - and showing other nations down. The primary purpose of History was to arise Nationalism or allegiance to the Monarch. We were a much more freer and open civilization, and did not have a concept of "Nation State". For us, India was, and still is a civilization much more than a Nation. And hence, did not need to fall to narrow and inconclusive science of History. So, in my opinion - to ask the question of "historicity" of Mahabharata is, in a way, losing the point and demeaning it to western standards. Instead read the Mahabharata and it's thousand adaptations - and immerse yourself in the joy of ancient wisdom!

There are many technical answers here to prove if these epics are real/fictional. All this debate is good as it would help Indian mythology to spread around the world. As an admirer and follower of Indian mythology, I would not like to give a definite yes or no. But we can safely assume that the attributed authors of these two epics are heavily inspired from real life characters and incidents in their life time. For example, Ved Vyas, the author of Mahabaharata is himself one of the characters in the epic. It is said that the rivalry between Pandavas and Kauravas is inspired from the real life rivalry of his Grand-Children. Also, it is believed that the kuru-kshetra war is inspired from a real war fought among nomadic herdsmen in the north of modern Delhi, which is now the town of Kuru-kshetra in the state of Haryana. Also, there are many geographical evidences in the present world which are described in these epics. Before analysing whether Ramayana or Mahabharata are historical works are not, we have to define history in the first place. The modern notion of what constitutes history, which is supposed to be “ scientific and objective “ in nature, is an Enlightenment concept of history developed during the 18th century . This is an European concept , which believes in using objective sources ( coins, inscriptions, texts, archaeology ) to critically analyse the evidence and reach conclusions based on “ reason and logic “. Due to colonialism and capitalism, the western notion of life has come to constitute a kind of “ global modernity “ for non western people. So, the objectivist or positivist notion of history developed in Europe became accepted as the dominant notion of history accross the world. This notion of history dubbed other ways of looking at the past — tribal geneologies, gods and goddesses, animals — as myths and superstitions which are fit to be discarded for “ civilizing “ the “ Savage, barbarian “ natives. Mahabharata and Ramayana fit into this discredited category of “ Oriental superstitions “. Since they do not conform to dominant notion of Western History, they are myths. What we tend to forget is that there are “ different ways “ of looking at the past across different cultures in this diverse world. Romila Thapar, the Indian historian, categories historical consciousness into two types — externalized history ( the western concept ) and embedded history ( where stories serve as vehicles for conveying images of the past ). Thus, Ramayana and Mahabharata do reflect a “ historical consciousness “, as, it clearly has a concept of “ looking back at the past “. The supernatural elements are most probably metaphors or allegories used to describe complex phenomenon, thought or philosophy. The ancients were not fools to include these for making us laugh , they did it with an educative purpose. So, Ramayana and Mahabharata cannot be strictly termed as “ history “ according to the modern sense of the term, but neither it is a myth ( I have serious reservations with the usage of this term ). They are , what we can say, “ embedded history “.

The only known archaeological record in this period is remains of Indus Valley civiization which show: No account of warNo usage of horses or chariotsNo description of figures even close to Rama or Krishna or any other historic character mentioned in both the epics.We do have however the following historical proofs: Evidence of floods and dislocation in Hastinapur area around 800–850BCMention of Krishna Vasudeva as a disciple king of Ghora Angirasa who has been dated to Upanishdic age of 800–850BCEvidence of a Sumerian king Rim Sin (Meaning Rim the Moon King) who united the Elamite empire around 1800BC including Iran, Afghanistan, Iraq and Indus valley which is later indus periodEvidence of Rim Sins sister being kidnapped and his efforts to rescue her over 15 yearsEvidence of his arrival in IVC areas to look for allies to fight his enemies to rescue his sisterEvidence of close confederacy between Sumerians and Indus Valley people and Indus valley, Sumeria and Iran having same culture called Elamite cultureEvidence of concept of Trinity and Avatara in earliest Sumerian religion around 2500BC which influenced Indus valley People and close correspondence between Trinity in hinduism and Trinity in Elamite religionMention of Rama in Rig Veda which is dated to 1200BC (due to Mittani inscriptions of 1400BC) and equivalent Ramses in Egyptian recordsAll this leads to conclusion that Ramayana was a popular folklore which was pre aryan and dating back to pre 1500BC in IVC about a powerful Sumerian king Rim Sin. The incoming Aryans made this popular folklore their own and appropriated the trinity concept of pre aryan Elamite religion prevalent in IVC and Iran/Sumeria.During the buddhist age around 1st century BC when monastims became popular and was weakening the state, the priestly class converted the folk story of Rim Sim into a full blown epic except this time the scene of action was not IVC/Afghanistan/Sumeria but all those locations which were part of major trade routes around 1st century BC including Lanka/South India/Ganges belt and were particularly in sway of buddhism.The Mahabharata was most certainly a minor civil war in Kuru Aryan Kingdom around 800BC which much like Rim Sins story became popular folklore and converted to an epic by the same period 1st century BC.Thus both Ramayana and Mahabharata were mythical stories written based on real events around 1st century BC to counteract the spread of Buddhism and its impact on state power .It is also not surprising that 1st century BC is also period when Pusyamitra Sunga came to power after overthrowing Mauryas and was a staunch believer in Hinduism and opposed monasticism of Buddhism. Clearly History is as much political as it is scientific.

For me, it does not matter that whether the incidents of Ramayana and Mahabharata actually took place or not. I enjoy reading them on the basis of faith and faith requires neither any proving nor disproving. When I place them in history, my rationality takes the better of me and pushes me into questions like: How could Hanuman fly? How could monkeys talk? How could Gandhari produce 100 sons? How could Ravana had ten heads? How could Sita enter fire and still remain unburnt? How could Krishna show such a magnificent Virat Roop that transcended over time and space? How could Arjuna go to heaven? Where heaven exists? Does it exist? And there are plenty of such questions which await our opinion if we place the epics in history. In such cases, we get suspended between real and unreal, proofs and theories. This further distracts us from the bhaavaarth, the essence of the epics. Maybe it's my retreating nature from such questions and my inability to answer them rationally that I consider Ramayana and Mahabharata as tales of wisdom, not necessarily real. Yet I say the Ramayana and Mahabharata are cyclical. They happen in every Yuga. They happen on my scale of faith. When that happens, I don't ask myself how can Hanuman fly? I ask why Hanuman flies? What makes him so devoted to Ram that he outgrows the animal within? How Krishna expanded himself doesn't bother me but why he expanded him does. I cannot answer how Hanuman teared apart his chest to show the presence of Sita Ram but I can answer why, what made Hanuman do it?  In the world of my belief and faith, they do happen. How? I don't know. Is knowing everything necessary? They just happen. Why? To give me a spiritual uplift at times, to allow me ponder over the wisdom encapsulated within their actions and to discover the voice of soul within. People may find it contradictory but that is how things are with most of the devotees. Absolute reality, that whether things really happened or not, does not bothers them. Through their faith, they make Ram and Krishna timeless by not restricting them with time and geography. Yet the epic happens for them, at a place rooted in their beliefs, which requires no rational or scientific explanation. So this word ‘real’ is very subjective to me. I believe that the epics happened. My belief has nothing to do with the absolute reality of the epic. Faith is powerful. It transforms a stone into a deity. It forms the very basis of our living. It's the faith that makes us feel that we will be alive tomorrow. That's all I am able to write at the moment. :-)

If you want to treat them as “history”, then they must be subjected to the Historical method, which tells us that historical claims must be independently verifiable. In that sense, events described in the Mahabharata or Ramayana - of talking rivers, magic, demons, lifting mountains on a finger… cannot be called “history”  Having said that, I am intrigued. Should we therefore say that Ramayana and Mahabharata are not “real”? What is real, anyway? I don’t want to say that these stories are not “real”, because they have a profound effect on the Indian culture. A dictionary says that real things are those which are not imagined or proposed. Things that “actually” happened or those that “actually” existed, in the physical world. But, to me, that is incomplete. I will gladly call the Mahabharata and the Ramayana “real”, because they have a profound impact on us. In my view, every attempt to say that these stories are real or not are made by people who really just want to thwart the message of these epics. Here is the situation - these epics are a part of India, and they are here to stay. How we deal with them is up to us. We can accept and admire these epics in all their divinity and misogyny, war and peace, love and hatred, jealousy and compassion. It’s all a part of these epics, and we can choose to talk about these and learn. Or, proving that all of this is “not real”, we can choose to ignore everything about the story. We can say that Krishna didn’t exist because there is no historical evidence. While that is still acceptable, some people choose to extend this logic to say that, therefore, these epics are a sham and should be rejected in their entirety.  The sad thing is that we are split between two groups - those who want to reject everything about these stories, and those who want to accept and blindly follow everything. Each group relies on “scientific and historical accuracy” to support their claim. But, sadly, each group is missing the point! Whether or not these stories are “real” does not matter. And that’s the point. The beauty of Mahabharata is in learning from the story, in reading it and getting to know so much about human nature and desires and actions. It’s the story which is beautiful, profound and a work of perfection! If you admire and respect the story, you don’t need any proof. And if you don’t admire and respect it, a thousand proofs won’t work for you! In that sense, I say this question is futile. And it is important that we stop trying to prove something. For example, you will see a random ‘news channel’ telecasting on an afternoon, “this is the place Lord Ram washed his feet!” as if we are to worship every such place. Why does it matter? We need to grow up and get our priorities sorted out.

Thanks for A2A. I believe the Ramayana and Mahabharata are based on real events, but then later retellings embellished the epics greatly and added to them. Heroes in the epics were later made larger-than-life with the passage of time, an example being Krishna, who was transformed from a master strategist to a God after many retellings. For more on this, see Seshadri Kumar's answer to What was the sole motive of Krishna behind the Kurukshetra war? The Mahabharata, based on version history and the references within, is deduced to have happened around the 10th or 9th century BC. (see van Buitenen for more on this). The original poem Jaya written to commemorate this had 25,000 verses; over time, this was expanded more and more by subsequent authors, until it came to 100,000 verses. van Buitenen gives a beautiful explanation of how the layers in the Mahabharata were added,which makes perfect sense...you should read it if you haven't yet. Look for his book on amazon - he translated three volumes, and you can find this in the Adi Parva that he translated. Your question as to whether this could have been pure fiction is valid. I contend, though, that it was not pure fiction, and I will tell you why. The Mahabharata as it exists today is used as a book on morality and religion. If you wanted to make up a book on morality and religion, you could do better than write the Mahabharata or the Ramayana. The reason is that the main characters in these books are often flawed. For instance, Rama in the Ramayana kills the Vanara king Vaali not in a direct fight, but by hiding somewhere and shooting an arrow at him without being seen. If you are creating a work of fiction, why show your lead character as committing what seems to be a rather ignoble act? They could have instead shown a grand fight between Rama and Vaali in which Rama, being a God, wins. Similarly, in the Mahabharata, the "virtuous" Pandavas defeat and kill Bhishma, Drona, Karna, Bhurishravas, and Duryodhana only by unfair means. If you wanted to write a book glorifying the Pandavas and Krishna, why show them doing these underhand things? If you were simply making up stuff, you could add to the glory of Arjuna by saying that he defeated and killed Bhishma, Drona, and Karna in fair and glorious fights.  You may lso like reading this other reply of mine in this connection: Seshadri Kumar's answer to  Mahabharata: How was Krishna justified in advising to kill people like Karna, Drona, Bheeshma, Duryodhana etc. ?) That is why I believe these books were based on actual events involving humans with imperfections. Over the course of time, some of them got elevated to the status of Gods. This should not surprise us. Even in modern history, the nation of Japan regarded its emperor as divine, even though he was eminently mortal, so why should we be surprised that this happened in ancient times in India?
