Thanks for the A2A..Good Question..why not let you in on what some of the professionals in the field think? I will basically here present the observations of the famed and best-selling Belgian Indologist,Dr. Koenraad Elst.  The Puranas are basically the history of India and the Gods as the Indians of first millenium AD saw it...They are heavily laced with mythology and supernatural events (but no more than the writings of the ancient Greek historians. Do refer Dr.Arvind Sharma on this).. But they do provide a comprehensive genealogy of Indian kings and priestly lineage right upto around 4000BCE (probably the time when the first Rig Vedic hymns were being composed)..The Puranas assert again and again that 1015 or 1050 years passed between birth of Parikshit (grandson of Arjuna) and the ascension of Mahapadma Nanda (historically dated to either 378BCE or 382BCE)..Given that Parikshit was born within a year of the Kurukshetra war, this would put the battle somewhere between 1432BCE-1393BCE.  Here I am quoting Dr. Koenraad Elst " The central event of the MBh is a chariot battle. Now, chariot battles were popular in a very specific window of history, viz. the bronze age when metallurgy was already sophisticated enough for strong and light chariot wheels; and before the rise of cavalry made chariots redundant. The first chariot found by archaeology dates to 2200 BC (Sintashta, Asian Russia). Its high tide in warfare was in the later 2nd and the early 1st millennium BC: many wars of that period were fought with chariots, e.g. the Trojan war of ca. 1200 BC. That is why the scriptural reference dating Pandava Arjuna's grandson Parikshit 1050 years before the coronation of Mahapadma Nanda (ca. 380 BC), i.e. in the 15th century BC, may well be right. The classical date, 32nd century BCE, is extremely unlikely to have seen chariot warfare, and for Oak's date of the mid-6th millennium BCE, this is simply impossible." The date of the chariot battle of Kadesh between the Hittites and the Egyptians roundabout 1274BCE also supports this claim. Now Indians generally tend to date the Mahbharata war to around 3139BCE..But this is a flaw as Dr. Koenraad Elst again points out: "Indians say that the war described in the Mahabharata took place in 3139 BCE. This is based on the length of the Four Ages given in the Puranas, a type of mythohistorical literature from the first millennium CE. The doctrine of Four Ages is very ancient, attested also in Greek and Germanic mythology, but their quantification is apparently linked with the precession of the equinoxes, discovered by Hipparchos ca. 150 BCE and introduced in India only in subsequent centuries. There are no pre-Hellenistic mentions of the fourth age starting in the 32th century BCE, 37 years after the Mahabharata war, as Hindus traditionally (i.e. Puranically) believe. The astronomical evidence of the Mahabharata itself, however, points to well after 2300 BC.  " And to draw your attention to one more important thing: Krishna WAS NOT seen as a divine being or as an avatara of Vishnu by his compatriots in the Pandava or Kaurava camp. It was only in later interpolations that he was raised to the status of avatara of Vishnu. The Bhagavad Gita is seen as a later development of may be some historical core message of Krishna..which was basically an awesome prep talk to a soldier before war...(Why to fear death when you will be reborn again and again?.If you win war you win glory on earth, if you lose and die you gain glory in heaven)...it was only later that may be some of the main philosophical points touched upon by Krishna was developed into the Bhagavad Gita...may be the orginal message was only 40-50 verses long instead of the 700 verses we have now....and the Mahabharata itself claims that the present 100,000 verse Mahabharata stems from the 24,000 verse Bharata which in turn stems from the 8,800 verse core Jaya text..we can be pretty sure that the core Jaya text was glorifying historical events. Dr. Koenraad Elst had this to say about the very ordinary human nature of Krishna in the epic: "even in the epic itself he is a down-to-earth war consultant and womanizer suffering an all too human fate, with most of the Bharata clan killed in the fraternal war in which he guides them, all his own relatives killing each other while drunk, and he himself dying in a silly hunting accident. It is only in later interpolations like the Bhagavad Gita that he gets deified." There is of course ample extra-Mahabharatical contemporary evidence for the historicity of Krishna. The Chandogya Upanishad refers to Krishna,Devakiputra or son of Devaki, and speaks of him as the pupil of Ghora Angirasa who is a priest of the sun according to Kausitaki Brahmana (refer to Dr. S. Radhahkrishnan's The Bhagavad Gita page 28) . After interpreting the meaning of sacrifice  and making out that the true payment for the priests is in the practice of vartues of charity and austerity, uprightness, non-violence and truthfulness, the Upanishad continues "When Ghora Angirasa explained this to Krishna,the son of Devaki, he also said, that, in the final hour , one should take refuge in these three throughts. "Thou art the indestructible (aksita), thou art the immovable (acyuta), thou art the very essence of life (prana)" There is great similarity between the teachings of Ghora Angirasa in the Upanishads and Krishna in the Gita...It's basically a derivation of the above three teachings that Krishna used to fashion Arjuna into a brave war commander...and then these teachings in turn developed into the Bhagavad Gita...The Principal Upanishads are generally dated between 1400BCE-500BCE...Niraj Mohanka pushes the dates quite convincingly back to 1900BCE. One More thing to remember that in the time of Mahbharata the Sraswati has already dried up..so this puts its in the post-1900BCE range  about Krishna becoming the defacto God/avatara of Vishnu/Supreme Deity/One of the Supreme Deities, Dr. Koenraad Elst had this to say: "The trouble already started with the Bhagavad Gita. I have it on good Hindu authority, but I have also seen it for myself, that the Gita is a work of “synthesis”. Then already, Hindus were enamoured of synthesis. Thus, this is where we first find the notion of an equality between three disciplines: karma yoga, “the discipline of action” (then meaning Vedic sacrifice, now moralistically interpreted as good works), jñana yoga, “the discipline of knowledge” (meaning Upanishadic knowledge of the Self, i.e. yoga proper), and bhakti yoga, “the discipline of devotion”. In fact, when Yajñavalkya introduces the notion of the Self, he pits its knowledge against the Vedic rituals. The ancient Vedas and esp. the Brahmanas (the technical manuals of ritual) are centred on karmakanda, “the (ritual) action half”, while the Upanishads are centred on jñanakanda, “the knowledge half”. While yogis would simply choose the latter, the Gita proposes a synthesis, viz. the third pole, bhakti. The book discusses a number of then-popular Hindu philosophies, but interjects in every chapter one sentence that does not follow from these philosophies at all, namely that all this shall be given to you if you are but devoted to Me, Krishna. You can read Patañjali’s Yoga Sutra, but you will not find Krishna there. You can read the Buddha’s teachings on meditation, but Krishna is not there. Yoga can perfectly exist without Krishna. Modern bhakti Hindus project their own bhakti beliefs on the whole of Hindu history. They deny the reality of change (both progress and degeneration) in Hindu history. In fact, it is they who realize the Westerners’ fond image of Hinduism as frozen in time, unchangeable. So, they rewrite the theory of yoga as dealing with God. In fact, the more God, the less yoga, and the more yoga, the less God." I will also provide some essential readings regarding the subject of dating Mahabharata. Whether the supernatural stuffs in the story are true or not, let it be left to the imagination..More important is the message of Dharma ..I have done less research on the historicity of Ramayana but I will leave you with some excellent works on Indian chronology by other people upto 4000BCE and beyond A Nation Without a History by Niraj MohankaThe Royal Chronology of India some essential wiritings of Dr. Koenraad Elst regarding dating Mahabharata The Arundhati omenAstronomical evidence and the UpanishadsPage on koenraadelst.blogspot.de The ever quotable Dr. Koenraad Elst had this to say on the Dharmic concept of Just War or Dharma Yuddha "The battle rages for eighteen days. The change it has wrought, is best realized by Krishna’s brother Balarama, who has missed the battle. He has gone on pilgrimage along the Saraswati river (already dried up in its lower course) and returns just at the end of the hostilities. He is amazed and indignant at the size of the destruction and the decline into non-Dharmic behaviour. But that is how war goes: at the start, as in 1914, you march off with a flower in your gun, singing songs of victory, you even play football with the enemy soldiers during breaks; but as soon as you have seen some of your comrades die, you get angry and eager for revenge by any means, so war becomes more cruel the longer it lasts. The epic is by no means a children’s story in black and white, or a hagiography for a saintly Krishna. The bad guys always have a decent motive or a legitimate excuse for their conduct (for instance, Duryodhana has welcomed the illegitimate son Karna after the latter was spurned by the Pandavas), and the good guys have their own past to blame for the misfortunes that befall them. They are all far from perfect, and the dharma yuddha is an ideal which they try to uphold as long as the going is good, but which they betray more and more as the battle gets grimmer.   The concept of Dharma Yuddha is akin to the later European concept of Just War. The Just War theory is linked with names like Saint Augustine, Saint Thomas Aquinas and Hugo Grotius. It lays down that war should only be started in self-defence, after attempts at a peaceful solution, and with a real chance of victory. During the war, the means used should be commensurate with the aim, non-combatants should be spared, and peace overtures from the other side should be answered. The same principles are already articulated briefly in the Dhanurveda and the Mahabharata." Hindu organization like Vishwa Hindu Parishad etc claim that question relating to existence of Rama cannot be simply resolved by scientific or historical findings. The Ramayana is one of two epics, the other being the Mahabharata, which have had a crucial influence in shaping the nature of Indian civilization. Many historians claim that Ramayana actually happened and is not a mythological folklore. There are many pre-historic drawings on its ceiling. An inscription in the cave that reads, ‘Parumaka naguliya lene’ further establishes a distinct link between Sita and the Cobra Hood cave. The Demons who guarded Sita while she was Ravana’s prisoner called her her Naguliya – one who was born off the ploughshare. Existence of Hanuman Garhi: Lord Hanuman is one of the most important characters of Ramayana and an ardent devotee of Lord Rama. Hanuman Garhi, now a temple is a place in Ayodhya, where Hanuman was waiting patiently for Lord Rama who was in exile. Hanuman Garhi temple is also famous for its strategic location. It is situated at such a height and at such a site, from where the sunrises and sunsets are artistically visible. It is also backed by the construction method used to build the bridge is mentioned in the Valmiki's text. Sync between time history and ages: Archaeological studies reveal that the first human inhabitation happened in Sri Lanka around 1,750,000 years ago and it’s been proved that the bridge’s age dates back to the same equivalent. To top it, the dates mentioned in the text of Valmiki matches with that of primitive age as well. Mystery of Floating stones: In Ramayan it is mentioned that the Ram Setu was built by Stones and these stone starts Floating on water by touch of Nala & Neel. Historians, over the years have tried to date the two epics by looking into various factors. For example, one of the factors taken into account was the commencement of KAL YUG upon the culmination of war in the Mahabharata. But this year, as perhaps calculated by Aryabhata, was found out be 3102 BC. This was believed to be too early for the kind of war described in Mahabharata. Another event, that is the flooding of Hastinapur, when correlated with archeological evidences, dated the war to 900 BC. But this too is not agreed upon by everyone. The poetic fantasies and exaggerations, combined with several Brahamanical accretions have made it very difficult for the historians to agree on a small range of time for both the epics. In general, it is agreed that both the epics, in it’s current versions, can be dated to the period between mid first millennium BC and mid first millennium AD.What is interesting, however, is that most of the historians agree that Ramayana, at least in it’s final form, was later than Mahabharata. This is contrary to traditional Hindu believes. Some of the arguments given for this assertion includes the geographical exploration of the two epics. The Mahabharata mainly centers around Hastinapur, which is westward to where Ramayana is centered around, the Ganga plains. Also, Ramayana extends south to Sri Lanka, whereas, the Mahabharata fails to explore beyond the Doab region. Although, some historians also believed that the war in Sri Lanka was an exaggeration of a war with a southern kingdom. But, even they believe that southward and eastward geographical exploration of the Ramayana does support the argument of Ramayana being written later than Mahabharata. Another argument to support this assertion is the social ambience of the two epics. The Mahabharata is a story of a clan based society (Yadavas, Pandavs, Kuru etc ), whereas, the Ramayana is the story of a Kingdom based society. This too suggests that Ramayana came later.As for the authors, the Mahabharata is traditionally attributed to Ved Vayas. But, it is widely accepted amongst historians that it has been subject of many accretions. Thus the epic in it’s present form cannot be attributed to just one person. Originally, it may have been just the story of the war. But, it has now seen the addition of many episodes, including the Bhagavadgita. It is believed by the historians that the narrative section is definitely older that the didactic section, which was added later. The original version of Ramayana is attributed to Valmiki. The war between Ram and Ravan is believed to depict the cultural gap between the North and the South at that time. The Kingdom of Kosala( Ram’ Kingdom) is presented as sophisticated and civilized. The southerners are depicted as uncivilized and barbaric, and refered to as Rakshashas, or demons. It is also believd that the original war may have taken place in the southern part of India, and was later transferred to Sri Lanka by editors later on. Sources- Romila Thappar and some others whom I cannot recall.

Did they happen exactly as in the epics? Not likely. Flying vimanas, nuclear weapons fired from bows, magic, etc. require strong evidence, and none at all are available. However, it is likely that the Mahabharata at least is based on a real war.  There is a  Battle of the Ten Kings (dasarajna) mentioned in the Rig Veda, which resulted in the Bharata clan settling in the Kurukshetra area. Did this provide the core for the Mahabharata? Unlikely, but it's an interesting thought. The Kuru Kingdom  is a historical one, and kings like Janamejaya and Parikhsit are mentioned in other Vedic texts. The Mahabharata sets its own first narration at a sacrifice performed by  Janamejaya, so presumably he was an influential king who had something to do with the creation of the epic. One can speculate that he funded the creation of the epic in some form to glorify himself and his ancestors, who feature prominently in it. Given that Vaisampayana appears as the first narrator, it's possible that he and his students may have been the authors. Attribution to Veda Vyasa, his guru, may have been done for reasons of increased prestige.  Creation of the epic itself is multi-layered. Vyasa is mentioned as the initial author, then Vaisampayana narrates it at Janamejaya's sacrifice, and this entire story is then narrated by Ugrasrava Srauti at a much later sacrifice by Rishi Saunaka. From this, one can speculate that the text went through multiple revisions and expansions, and what we have may not be the original version. There are traditions of earlier versions called Jaya (8000 verses) and Bharata (24000) verses before the current version called Mahabharata came into being.  To my knowledge, no archaeological evidence for the war that formed the core of the epic exists.

Both are as true as can be, or based on actual events and personalities who lived, going by the widespread and long standing cultural, geographical, pre-historical, scriptural,  and even astronomical evidence. The Ramayana seems to have occurred around 7000 years ago and the Mahabharata around 5000 years ago. (Google Astronomical Dating) Both are narrations by contemporaries, Not accounts or story telling in hindsight. Valmiki, author of Ramayana, lived during Rama's time (Sita brought up her children in his ashram) and Vyasa, author of Mahabharata, was an elder in the Kuru dynasty. Both the dynasties have a long lineage, before and after the epic events, which are recorded in great detail in other scriptures. (Every king's name is given!) Both have character appearances of people who appeared to have lived independent, otherwise unconnected lives, commonly known in mythology and pre-history (scriptural history) The entire subcontinent of India is peppered with places where various instances of the two epics were played out. It is marked by still standing archeological evidence, temples and folklore. The route of Rama from Ayodhya, during his exile, and then in search of Sita to the South, and then on to Lanka is quite clearly delineated and there are markers right down the route. His journey is quite eventful, and every event has its place still identified today. In fact it has been, traditionally, and still is a pilgrimage route. We can still see the land bridge built by his 'monkey army' in satellite photos.[This of course can be questioned by skeptics as a natural formation under the sea that is being touted as Rama's bridge!] This folklore exists even in Sri Lanka (where Ravana lived, where Sita was imprisoned and the war took place to free her) and is the motivation for much tourism in that country. The routes of the Pandavas during their exile and Arjuna during his 'punishment' is also delineated and can be identified even today. Both are corroborated by equally ancient scriptures and folklore from other places in the subcontinent, even when thousands of miles away. For instance there is mention of the a king from an earlier Pandya kingdom who took part in the war on the side of the Pandavas in ancient Tamil literature. Whatever the evidence, it is an exercise in appeasement of intellectual curiosity. The reality is that, as works of 'epic' proportions both are unparalleled in their scope and canvas and content in every which way. And this is an understatement!

When children learn these stories they understand that life is not about living happily ever after it is about struggle, sacrifice, and service to humanity.

Whether or not the Ramayana actually happened as described by Valmiki, with cleverly articulated facts, stories, anecdotes, is immaterial. The objective of the epic of Ramayana cannot be found in it’s historical, factual accuracy. The objective of this beautiful epic is philosophical, cultural, moral, and spiritual enquiry. It is written in such a thoughtful and engaging manner that the problems faced by the protagonists and the antagonists, are still relatable and hold relevance to our present. It has been written with the objective of uplifting our limited consciousness. What matters is whether or not the saga of the Ramayana is a living reality for you. R_A_M_A_Y_A_N_A ‘Ra’ means light, ‘Ma’ means within me, in my heart. So, Rama means the Light within Me. Rama was born to Dasharath & Kousalya. Dasharath means ‘10 Chariots’. The ten chariots symbolize the 5 sense organs (Gnanendriya) & 5 organs of action (Karmendriya). Kousalya means ‘Skill’. Hence, the skillful rider of the 10 chariots can give birth to Rama. When the 10 chariots are used skillfully, Radiance is born within. Rama was born in Ayodhya. Ayodhya literally translates to ‘a place where no war occurs’. Thus, when there is no conflict in our mind, then the radiance can dawn. The Ramayana is not just a story which happened long ago. It has philosophical, spiritual significance embedded deep within, the gems of which are available to those who delve into its depths and have the clarity of the mind, purity of the heart and synergy of the soul to access it. It is said that the Ramayana is happening in our own body. Our Soul is Rama, Our Mind is Sita, Our Breath or Life-Force (Prana) is Hanuman, Our Awareness is Laxmana and Our Ego is Ravana. When the Mind (Sita), is stolen/hijacked by the Ego (Ravana), then the Soul (Rama) gets restless. Now the Soul (Rama) cannot reach the Mind (Sita) on its own. It has to take the help of the Breath – the Prana (Hanuman) by being in Awareness (Laxmana). With the help of the Prana (Hanuman), and Awareness(Laxmana), the Mind (Sita) reunites with The Soul (Rama) and The Ego (Ravana) is vanquished. In reality, Ramayana is an eternal phenomenon happening all the time, in our own existence, in our own cosmos, in our own experiential reality. It’s just that we are not sensitive enough to grasp it. We are a judgmental generation; which places far too much importance on intellect and little to no importance on our consciousness. So we dismiss such an epic because it contains irrational elements that do not appeal to our finely tuned scientific senses. When we finally understand that the epic, regardless of whether or not it actually occurred, we’d know that the true purpose of this epic is to understand the human dilemma and find ways to uplift ourselves.

There are people who vouch for their authenticity and there are people who pooh-pooh them. My view is based on my experience - when I write stories, I have a basic idea which I keep intact and change names and incidents to hide the identities of real persons. Writing is a very difficult and energy-draining task. All world-famous writers from all countries and all languages have accepted that writing does not come easily. That’s why it is difficult for me to believe that Vyas composed and recited the Mahabharata while Ganesh wrote it down. Frankly speaking, the number of characters, relationships, incidents are so complicated that it is impossible for anyone - even the genius of genii - to write it all in one flow. It must have taken decades from beginning to completion. Anyway, I don’t want to strike up a debate between faith and reality. For those who believe the Ramayana and the Mahabharata happened exactly as they are written, I don’t want to debate. I’d rather spend my time doing something useful.

This reminds me of something which I read a while ago. Jawaharlal Nehru, imprisoned in Ahmednagar Fort, contemplating the past and future of the then young yet very old and mythical idea of India wrote a very enlightened passage on this very topic. I am neither as articulate nor qualified enough to interpret Nehru’s musings. So, I will reproduce that passage here and it is for you to decide whether the question of these old and powerful stories is real, warrants an answer. “If people believed in the factual content of these stories, the whole thing was absurd and ridiculous. But as soon as one ceased believing in them, they appeared in a new light, a new beauty, a wonderful flowering of a richly endowed imagination, full of human lessons. No one believes now in the stories of Greek gods and goddesses and so, without any difficulty, we can admire them and they become part of our mental heritage. But if we had to believe in them, what a burden it would be, and how, oppressed by this weight of belief, we would often miss their beauty. Indian mythology is richer, vaster, very beautiful, and full of meaning. I have often wondered what manner of men and women they were who gave shape to these bright dreams and lovely fancies, and out of what gold mine of thought and imagination they dug them. Looking at scripture then as a product of the human mind, we have to remember the age in which it was written, the environment and mental climate in which it grew, the vast distance in time and thought and experience that separates it from us. We have to forget the trappings of ritual and religious usage in which it is wrapped, and remember the social background in which it expanded. Many of the problems of human life have a permanence and a touch of eternity about them, and hence the abiding interest in these ancient books. But they dealt with other problems also, limited to their particular age, which have no living interest for us now.”

I think you mean to ask whether the epics narrate historical events accurately. I would reply - Not at all. The epics were not intended to convey historical events, but rather to partly convey certain philosophical points of view and to serve as a model for other classical sanskrit literature. There will be a large number of (mostly ignorant) people who will claim (based on astrology etc) that the epics are from before 3000 BCE. But anybody who has read the epics in the original sanskrit themselves and understood what they are trying to say, will not accept these 3000 BCE stories. Let us see traditional references to the epics. The earliest authorities to mention the epics were Pāņini and Kauţilya (both of whom lived in the 4th century BCE). There is significant proof that the earliest form of both epics are from the 4th century BCE. That was at the end of the vedic period just about one century after the oldest upanishads (Chāndogya & Bŗhadāraņyaka) were composed. The main stories described in the epics never took place at any point of time. However some of the people and places that they mention are not entirely fake so the epics are not completely false.. for example the Buddha did exist (just one century before the epics), and he is mentioned in both epics. The epics mention existence of the janapadas (kingdoms) such as kurus, pañcālas, madra, kośala, videha, kāśi, avanti etc.. which were real. But to know what is true and whatis not true in the epics, one should study them seriously and not repeat what the ignorant people say based on fake astronomical data. Vālmīki and Vyāsa had no intention to write down a factual report of their historical knowledge, that was not their purpose. Their intention was to compose a kāvya that could serve certain scholarly and ethical purposes for future generations of Indians. That is the purpose which they have served anyways.

I would keep my answer for Ramayan as Mahabharata has been well analysed by Ajit Narayana in his answer here, Why was Dhristadyumna made the supreme commander for Pandavas given the availability of Arjuna? Is there a reason they don't want Arjuna to lead the troops? Lets dig down on psychology.  Thinking or reasoning is classified in two distinct types; Propositional and Narrative. Propositional argument would be to defend or disprove a certain proposition. It builds on logic, describe the events in rational order and is objective. Physics, chemistry, Biology, Mathematics, most of our science fields fall in this reasoning concept. More details here: Descriptive knowledge , Propositional attitude  Whereas, Narrative builds on emotional part of our brain. It builds on our experiences, experience of feelings, not time or years. Narrative is set of events and characters woven to make the audience feel the desired emotions. In common metaphor language, proposition is food for our logical brain and narrative is for our hearts. More on Narrative: Narrative paradigm , Narrative preaching   Both, propositional and narrative methods are used for teaching, preaching and transform humans for a desired outcome. In most of scientific studies, Narrative has been found to be much more effective. More details of studies are here: The Place of Story in the Study of Teaching and Teacher Education , Narrative and Propositional Reasoning in an Instructional Context  Now, keep in mind, Ramayan is a narrative, not a proposition. Listening to Ramayan is expected to make audience feel a certain emotion. Ask yourself, what you felt when you first heard the story? Leave aside the curiosity and amazement. These emotions are to catch the audience's attention, preparing or grooming us for final delivery or assault.  In the narrative, sequence of events goes like this: Fortunate human born as prince, peaceful kingdom, happy prince, politics unfold, loses his Home, depressed prince, wander in forest, helped by unknowns, loses wife, almost broken, help a stranger, human bonding, get new friends, make a gang, attack another gang, kills opponent king, get his wife back, returns Home...Victorious, become a king.... ...Happy king and queen, politics unfold, queen loses Home, move to forest, helped by ascetics, goes through labor, delivers twins, kids grow up, confront their father, short fight, mother and kids return to claim their right, mother is humiliated again, dies, kids get their right, King is depressed and dies. First part have 'Contamination' coding sequence, followed by a slight 'Redemption' sequence. In contamination sequences, things may go from very good to bad or from barely acceptable to worse. In a redemption sequence, a demonstrably "bad" or emotionally negative event or circumstance leads to a demonstrably "good" or emotionally positive outcome. The second part is extension of initial 'Contamination' sequence. It is an emotionally intense story of suffering.  The resulting outcome in audience brain is 'Empathy' for the storyteller. Storyteller become focus of empathy from the audience.  The emotion which I felt; "Help the Stranger". As humans, most of the times, we go through these emotions, feeling lost, depressed and broken. The force of these emotions is very strong. It rams in to our little brain and like a rammed bus, we lose control, we lose awareness or consciousness or mindfulness. In Pali (language of Ganges and surrounding plains in 8-4th century BC), word for awareness, consciousness, mindfulness is Sati. Refer dictionary here: The Pali Text Society's Pali-English dictionary   Situations may force us to lose our Sati. When we have lost Sati, we should help each other. This is part of human bonding. We should be open to welcoming strangers, make them friends. With a little help from friends, we can get our Sati back.  Here, it gets interesting. Words themselves tell the story. I was looking for root words, old meaning, etymology of character names used in Ramayan. Sita or Sati was easy. Same word is used in multiple narratives [Dead Sati and mad Shankara, odd couple though strong philosophy]. We still use Sati in our common language; "Mati maari gayi thee". Finding "Ram" was also not so difficult. In English, we still use "Ram" multiple times; ram the door, rammed in a bus, Ram the male goat. In English, it means, force, forceful, strong-head. In Arabi, "Ram" is used in "Ramadan". "Ram" their means "very hot, red hot". In Avestan, (Zorastrian scripture language) which is as much ancient as Sanskrit, it means "peace (lit.)" [Avestan Dictionary]. Inference of these would be, "Ram" denotes 'force of our strong emotions' or 'being peace with our emotions'. "Lanka" is generic for 'hilly place'. Refer to the usage in Buddhist stories on 7-10th century AD. One story of Lakshminkara says that the princess was married to prince of 'Lankapuri'; Chhinnamasta . Here, note that by 8th century India, locals were classified as tribal or lower caste. The class system had turned and had changed completely from 200 BC. Lakshminkara is now worshiped as 'Chamunda'; 82nd Mahasiddhi. Similarly, 'Ravan' is not meant 'man with loud voice', it meant 'soul'.  One possible interpretation can be: "A distressed person, in emotionally charged state, killed soul when he lost his awareness. He regained it, to lose it again forever." Note that Indian ancient philosophies had a concept of 'Anata', 'there is no I or self'. Soul represents 'I'. There was no concept of 'soul' in Indian tradition. Soul entered in theology only around 5-7 century AD.  If you find this interesting, you can search for different variation for Ramayana, across different communities in India. One Gond community, in fact, worship 'Ravan' as their 'dharmaguru'. Omar Rashid on Ravan worship . Older version of Ramayan also didn't depict Ram as god or Ravan as Devil. Both were shown as humans stuck in difficult situations. Here, note few oddities with Ramayan. Ramayan writer was Valmiki. He was not a Brahmin by birth, however, an outcast or tribal. In some stories, he is also portrayed as a short-time robber, living in forest. Point is that the Ramayan originated outside Brahminic tradition and later absorbed in. It is quite odd that the sect known for their claim to superiority, let this oddity continue. Next odd part is that as per Indian tradition, storytelling was not Brahman's profession. Brahmans were administrators, thinkers, strategist, however, not storyteller or writer/artist. Storytelling work was considered lower class, Charak, at least till 5th century. What forced Brahman's to become storyteller, we don't know. Another odd part is Ravan was Brahman (claimed as per his father side), whereas, Ram was not. It can be interpreted as debacle of a Brahman king by an outsider!!  Great stories have life of their own. They evolve, transform, take multiple shape in the hands of skilled storytellers. Ramayan is such a great story. As a narrative, it has been used by many great storytellers to make people accept new strangers in their fold, as well as, please their sponsor. Even debating on what was original version is fruitless exercise. Here, I would refer to a similar pursuit by christian folks on existence of Jesus Christ. Das Leben Jesu'  written by David Strauss in 1846 concluded at the end,"It doesn't matter if Jesus was real or not. It is still real though, how many lives he has impacted, how many people he has helped, how many human bridges he has made."  "Ram se bada Ram ka naam"

We are caught between two extreme views. Some people dismiss everything from India’s past as myth. Others take all ancient texts literally. What are the Ramayana and Mahabharata supposed to be? Let me give an interesting analogy to help understand this. Let us say that we are in the year 4000 A.D., roughly 2,000 years in the future. Due to various disruptions, historical documents from the 20th century have been destroyed. You, as a historian, living in 4000 A.D. want to understand what was happening in India in the late 20th century. The only historical artefact you are able to find is the VCD of an ancient movie! Somehow, you are able to use the technology of your day and play the movie, and somehow you are able to understand the ancient language used. This movie from 2,000 years back has a tall, lanky hero, named Vijay. This honest dude suffers because of the many corrupt people that he encounters. His family undergoes a lot of trouble. Eventually, Vijay gets so angry that he fights the system. Without any support from anyone, using just his strong fists, he kills an evil policeman, a greedy businessman and a corrupt politician. Of course, he also sings some romantic songs to a heroine in the middle of the movie! As a historian living in 4000 A.D., how should you interpret this ‘historical’ evidence? Here are your options: Vijay existed exactly as portrayed. There really was such a singing superman in the 20th century who could fight all kinds of strong and evil enemies, and destroy them on his own.This is all nonsense. How can such a superman exist? How can he also sing songs? Ignore the VCD entirely as evidence. We can learn nothing from it.Don’t worry whether Vijay really existed exactly as portrayed. Understand the nature of society and try to apply those lessons to today’s times to make a better future. For example: Corruption can be a huge problem. The system needs to be supportive of those who wish to fight the evils of society. Only a free and democratic society would have allowed such movies to be made where the powerful were being shown as evil and were getting defeated by a common man.The fair and reasonable approach is the third one. Apply the same to the Ramayana and Mahabharata. In fact, as per Indian tradition, that is what we are supposed to do. These Epics (and many other texts) are called ‘Smriti’ texts. They are subject to change based on prevailing societal norms. The purpose of these texts is to help society for all times. Taking such texts literally doesn’t do justice to the immense value in them. Ignoring them, or brushing them off, is intellectual arrogance of the small mind.

Ramayana and Mahabharata are the two itihasas and there are many Puranas. The Itihasas are epics and let us know them a little better … Some facts and Interpretations…. Ramayana Sage Valmiki’s Ramayana is the most well known Ramayana version. But there are many retellings of the epic Indian Languages Ananda Ramayana and Adbhuta Ramayana- addendums by Valmiki with some extra storiesRamayana is also included in summary in Mahabharata ((in the Ramopakhyana Parva of the Vana Parva), Bhagwata Purana, Vishnu Purana and Agni PuranaAgastya Ramayana by Sage AgastyaYoga Vasistha (Vasistha Ramayana) , a dialogue between Guru Vashishta and Rama, expounding Basics of Advaita by ValmikiAdhyatma Ramayana extracted from the Brahmanda Purana by Sage Vyasa - 1000 BCRamavtaram by Kamban in Tamil - 12th century ADRanganatha Ramayanam by Gona Budda Reddy in Telugu - 14th century ADSaptakanda Ramayana in Assamese by Madhava Kandali - 13th century ADRamcharitmanas in Awadhi by Goswami Tulsidas - 1576 ADKrittivasi Ramayan in Bengali by Krittibas Ojha, - 15th century ADVilanka Ramayana in Oriya by Sarala Das - 15th century ADBhavartha Ramayana in Marathi By Sant Eknath - 16th century ADRamayanu in Konkani by Krishnadasa Shama - 15th century ADKannassa Ramayanam in Malayalam by Niranam Ramapanicker - 16th century ADAdhyatma Ramayanam Kilipattu in Malayalam by Thunchaththu Ezhuthachan - 16th century ADTulsi-Krta Ramayana (adaptation of Ramcharitmanas) in Gujarati by Premchand Swami - 17th century ADPothi ramayana in UrduRamavatara Charita in Kashmiri - 19th century ADAdbudha Ramayanam and Ramaswamedham in Kannada by Nanadalike Lakshminarayan - 1895/98Other religions Buddhism - Dasarata Jataka where Rama and Sita are depicted as siblings.Jainism - Paumachariyam , a Jaina version where all characters are mortals engaged in internal conflict over morality and ethicsRamayana versions Outside India Burma Yama Zatdaw is unofficially Myanmar's national epic, is the Burmese version of the Ramayana. The names of the characters, in general, are Burmese transliterations of the Sanskrit names, thus Rama becomes Yama and Sta becomes Thida and Ravana becomes Yawana.Cambodia Reamker is a Cambodian epic poem, based on the Ramayana . The name means "Glory of Rama". It adapts the Hindu ideas to Buddhist beliefs and shows the balance of good and evil in the worldIndonesia Kakawin Ramayana is a Javanese rendering of the Ramayana. The Javanese Ramayana differs markedly from the original . The first half of this Ramayana is similar to the original Sanskrit version, while the latter half is divergent to the point of being unrecognizable. One of the many major changes is the inclusion of the all-powerful Javanese indigenous deity dhayana Guardian God of Java Semar (in Balinese literature known as Twalen) and his misshapen sons, Gareng, Petruk, and Bagong who make up the numerically significant four Punokawan or "clown servants"There are also versions of Ramayana in Laos, Nepal, Malaysia, Philippines Thailand and Tibet Info Source :Versions of Ramayana The story of the Ramayana is so powerful that so many retellings and interpretationsSymbolical references to the Human nature in Ramayana  (Image Source: Bing Search from Quora) There was a king Dasaratha who was terribly attached to all things worldly. He represents the blind worldly attachment . He had three queens, The eldest Kaushalya symbolises competency. The second wife is Kaikeyi, who represents Jealousy and The third wife Sumati represents Equanimity. When attachment is tinged with jealousy, results are not good Rama represents the Intellect and the divinity within usBharata represents ValuesLakshmana Represents CommitmentShatrugna represents DedicationSita represents empathyEmpathy along with intellect leads to happiness… irrespective of the environmentCommitment without intellect is of no valueDedication without Values is worthlessSo when Jealousy dominated attachment, intellect along with Commitment and Empathy was banished. Luckily we can sustain temporarily based on values and dedication   (Image Source: Bing Search from Quora) The Crisis is caused my the Many headed demon of Desires , called ravana in the ramayana. The first thing that gets kidnapped by our strong obsessive desires is empathy. So when the intellect seeks solutions, the support of Hope is needed, therein Hanuman enters the Ramayana. To locate empathy, he has to cross the ocean of pathos to get to the golden island of greed, Lanka. The multi headed desires rule the Island of greed and empathy is held hostage. Once with the help of hope, we see the faint glimpse of empathy, we are ready to cross the sea of pathos and self pity with the help of the Hope, we can go ahead and destroy desires and greed and rediscover our empathy and Humanity. Mahabharata The Mahabharata is the longest known epic poem and is "the longest poem ever written". Its longest version consists of over 100,000 shloka or over 200,000 individual verse lines (each shloka is a couplet), and long prose passages. About 1.8 million words in totalMahabharata is the analogical equivalent of a human being. We as a human are always fighting the war within between Good and Evil.  Krishna Advising Krishna on the Battlefield (Image Source: Bing Search from Quora) The Analogies in Mahabharata  (Image Source: Bing Search from Quora) The Kauravas Dhritarashtra represents blind attachment and ambition Ambition of Dhritarashtra blinded his good sense and made him support his sonUndue Attachments blinds a person and makes him forsake the path of righteousnessGandhari represents how attachments blinds our intellect, willinglyDuryodhan represents the unfettered Ego Unfettered Ego can cause great destructionThe myriad siblings of ego are desires which without discipline will drive us towards the ledge of destructionShakuni represents the Inherent negativity and selfishness in us Shakuni is representation of the negative emotions in us which prey on our ego and unleash destructionBheeshma represents the power of will A will directed towards a damning cause is not of any benefit to us (Image Source: Bing Search from Quora) The Pandavas Pandavas represent the absolute Human values Yudhisthira represents HonestyBheema represents StrengthArjuna represents KnowledgeNakula and Sahadeva represent the Twin values of Equanimity and Wisdom The Detached Vidura represents the conscience A conscience can be suppressed if the negativity is strong enoughKrishna represents the Intellect and inherent divinity Intellect Judges the right and wrong, Adhering to Intellect will enable good actions (Image Source: Bing Search from Quora) The Inner Kurukshetra is always active The Inner war in the inner Kurukshetra (inner field of thoughts) reflects in our Karma kshetra (external plane of actions). If we don't realise our inherent divinity the kaurava in us, the blind ambition , unfettered Ego, the selfishness will determine the will and will win. If we realiste the goodness in us and given the right direction by the intellect, we can leverage our positivity to be happy and pandavas will win. So Krishna the divinity is there in all… but will you choose him ?  Thus the Ramayana and Mahabharata are epics that have a lot of analogic symbolism understanding which will help us on our path of being a better human beings !!!

Why one more date based on the astronomical evidence quoted from the Mahabharata? I have made this effort for the following reasons: All the previous dates by various scholars are from misunderstood quotes, incorrect translations and incorrect conversions between the Gregorian calendar and the Indian astronomical calendar. These scholars here spent a lot of effort to come up with theses dates, and must be commended. However, these dates, if they do not match with all of the original quotes, cannot be accepted.Mahabharata & Krishna have been declared as mythology by the Western Indologists from the 19th Century until now. Some Indian scholars and leaders also believe the same. Therefore, I decided to investigate further. I believe in the saying, “investigate before castigate,” and Ronald Regan’s famous quote, “trust but verify.”Without relying on the stories and myths, I wanted to investigate purely on astronomical and scientific facts and phenomena like the conjunctions, eclipses, earthquakes, meteor showers and comet sightings. Since the powerful PCs with very accurate astronomical programs like Planetarium have become available, it is possible to construct the sky map of any day and time in the past and review the positions of the planets and other astronomical events. A whole new science called “Archaeoastronomy” has now evolved. Eclipses have become very predictable and accurate now, and are a great tool to date the past events. There may be no written or archeological evidence of the ancient past, but the sun, moon and stars are still the same and move per the same natural rules. Therefore, I decided to research the past astronomical phenomena and verify if the epic is history or fiction.Mahabharata is the closest epic to our time and is replete with many references to the astronomical phenomena. Krishna’s Bhagvat Gita is the most unique philosophical gem; but it would be interesting to see if it came from a real person and time.My research took me about 2 years of continuous study of the original critical Sanskrit Mahabharata (published by the Bhandarkar Oriental Studies Institute in Pune after 60 years of research).I used 4-5 different computer programs to compare the accuracy before I finalized on the latest Cyber Sky Planetarium program based on JPL (Jet Propulsion Laboratory) ephemeris 404, with an accuracy of ½ to 1 arc seconds for the periods 3000 BCE and older, and the Delta T value of less than 23 hours.The full results of my research will be published in a forthcoming book entitled Astronomical Proof of the Mahabharata War and Sri Krishna. The book will include the original Shlokas (stanzas) with translation, detailed computer maps of each event, and its Panchang (Indian astronomical ephemeris) positions of the Sun, Moon, planets, and comets.This current article is a summary of the salient features in the book. I wish to take the readers on the same journey I took while researching.The first item of the task was to find the century of the Mahabharata War. The Mahabharata epic is full of the time references right up to the war that Dwapar Yuga (the 3rd part of the 4 Yuga system) is ongoing and the Kaliyuga (the 4th part) would be coming soon. The Surya Sidhanta, a very ancient treatise on the Indian astronomy, mentions that when a new Yuga starts, all 7 planets will line up along the ecliptic (the Earth’s annual path) in the constellation Pisces, just before Aries on a Phalguni Amavasya day (the last day of the year).There could be a solar eclipse on that day. The Prajapati Smriti and the Matsya Puran provides the same prediction. Western translators of these scriptures doubted this; because it does not make sense that so many planets moving in their own orbits millions of miles apart at high speeds, can line up in one sign on the ecliptic line on a specific day and time.The Gregorian calendar date for this event is February 18, 3102 BCE at 2:27:30 AM. Anybody with a good astronomy software can verify that this event if did indeed occur. Now, the eastern as well as the western astronomers have all accepted this date for the start of the Kaliyuga. A map on the last page will verify this. It does not show the North Node (Rahu), but both Rahu and Ketu (the south node) were in the same line 180 degrees apart.This event has not happened for thousands of years before or thereafter. The closest recorded grand conjunction recorded, was in China in 1953 BCE, of 5 planets. With the establishment of the accepted Kaliyuga start date, the dates for Mahabharata War which were after 3102 BCE, are not applicable.These include Professor N. Achar (3067 BCE), Dr. Balkrishna (2559 BCE), Dr. K.S Raghvan and Dr. Iyengar (3067 BCE), R. Vaidya (2789 BCE). Only scholars Dr. P.V. Vartak (5561 BCE) and Dr. P.V. Holay (3143 BCE) had dates earlier. Out of the two, Dr. Vartak’s date is almost 2500 years earlier and so may not be acceptable. Now, shlokas (stanzas) in the Vishnu Puran, 38th chapter (5.38.8), Bhagvat Puran (1.18.6) and Brahma Puran (212.8), all state that the Kaliyuga started the moment Sri Krishna died.In Mahabharata Stri Parva, Queen Gandhari, mother of Kauravas had cursed Sri Krishna that in spite of being cable to prevent it, he watched the terrible slaughter of all of her sons and relatives, Therefore, Krishna would die in similar circumstances with his kith and kin, alone, wandering in a deserted place from a very frivolous weapon in 36 years.The Kaliyuga start date of 2-18-3102 BCE did also have a solar eclipse and a back to back lunar eclipse in two weeks similar to the Mahabharata War. There were earthquakes with meteor showers on both dates, and on the lunar eclipse day, a giant tsunami drowned the Dwarka city, which Krishna had advised to vacate.With Krishna’s death also established now on 2-18-3102 BCE, his birth dates by scholars Dr. Vartak (5626 BCE), n. Achar, Sampath Ayengar and Sheshgiri (3112 BCE), are no more applicable.Now we will proceed to place the Mahabharata War start’s month and day. Again, as written in Mahabharata, Bhishma, the grandfather of both the Kauravas and Pandavas, passed away on a winter solstice day at midnight, when the moon was in Rohini (Alderberan) star.Bhishma declares that it has been 68 nights since the war started, and 58 nights, since he was lying on the bed of arrows. As the Sun has turned to go north, he is ready to die. The winter solstice was on January 14 in that time period. The day was Magh month (bright half, eight’th day per the Indian calendar).Counting backwards, 7 nights of Magh month, plus 30 days of Pousha month plus 30 days of Margashirsha month, the 68 night and the war start day would be the Kartik month Amavasya (new moon day).This would be on November 6th.It is well known from the Mahabharata quote in which Krishna gives the message to Karna, that the month of Margashirsha was very suitable and so the war should start on a Shakra Amavasya day (the day when the moon would be in Indra’s star of either Vishakha or Jyeshtha). The night before the war, Sage Vyas, who made several astronomical observations, mentions that he has seen the Lunation periods 14, 15, 16 days apart but never 13 days apart (tithis to be exact.A day is not a tithi, since a tithi is based on the lunar phase at the sunrise and when the difference between the Sun and the Moon is 12 degrees). He also mentions it to be an Amavasya with an unseen solar eclipse, followed by a lunar eclipse in 13 tithis.Like all scholars, I also took 36 years per the Gandhari’s curse, added to 3102 BCE to find the eclipses around November, from the program, “Lunar Phases and Eclipses”. However, there were no back to back November eclipses found in years from 3102 to 3140.The only year which met all the eclipses criteria was year 3126 BCE, when there was Amavasya on 5th and 6th November (Amavasya and solar eclipse started at 8:37 PM on 5th) and the following full moon in 13 tithis (not days) on November 19-20, both days. The earlier lunation also had occurred 13 tithis before on October 21-22 (Kartik Purnima).Since all these events matched except the 36th year, I revisited the original verse, and found out that there were two different letters used in the Sanskrit word for 36th. One which all scholars had accepted was “shati trimshe” (in the 36th year). But the Bhandarker critical edition gave the word “shati trymshe,” meaning in the part of 36 years. (When people write down words recited by rote memory for generations such mistakes are normal). So the curse did have finite circumstances but not the finite time. Thus our war start date of November 6th, 3126 BCE matched of all the quotes and criteria. In those days, large number of years was grouped as Tapas or 12 years. 36 years represented the maximum 3 Tapas time, which actually happened in 2 Tapas or 24 years or 2/3rd part of 36 years.theI proceeded further to check the dates of all associated events for a match with computer generated sky maps, planet by planet. They all did match including two surprise observations about Neptune and Uranus! There would be more interesting information about the Rohini Shakat Bheda (piercing the star Alderberan Cart) by Saturn, which is indicative of terrible manslaughter.I will present the summary of this information in the next article to follow. I will provide more information about why the western scholars, as well as Indian scholars, missed these dates and how Archaeoastronomy in this computer age, works (when the times are converted properly).Kaliyuga map with alignment of 7 planets along Earth’s ecliptic (the Earth’s annual path) in the constellation Pisces This article is not my creation. Let me start in this way, We are living in an era in which everything has to be correct on the basis of our logics . If something is not fitting into our small window of logics(which varies person to person by the way) we say it's myth or incorrect. So if everything (which does not fit into our logic) is myth , what would you say about Magic ? I remember a story when in 1913, Srinivasa Ramanujan, a 23-year old shipping clerk from Madras, India, wrote to Hardy (and other academics at Cambridge), claiming, among other things, to have devised a formula that calculated the number of primes up to a hundred million with generally no error. The self-taught and obsessive Ramanujan had managed to prove all of Riemann’s results and more with almost no knowledge of developments in the Western world and no formal tuition. He claimed that most of his ideas came to him in dreams. Now in this also if I put my logic to explain the last line that the ideas came to Ramanujan in dream, I won't be able to expain it. Does it mean that it was a myth ? No!! The content of one Ramayana may be different from the other but the existence of Ram, Sita and Ravan is consistent. That's the truth. I might not know anything about my great great grandfather but I can't deny his existence for lack of evidence or how else would I be here? Similarly Rama's existence need not be proved by historical procedure. What benefit are you going to get if you deny the existence of Rama? Why do you want to try to prove he is not there? Therefore our epics and itihasas including Ramayana and Mahabharata should be treated as historical sources.

Let's start with History word. Originated in Greece it was an English translation of “Itihas” (इतिहास); which means meant to be or bound to happen. It was always the same as happened in Greek and Indian mythology. Some points: Devas vs Acura and Celtic vs Fomorian In Hindu mythology, the constant fight is between good and evil - the good represented by the devas (the gods) and the evil represented by the asuras (the demons). The asuras are the chief tormentors of the devas.  Similarly, Greek mythology is all about the Celtic gods of life and light, who wage a constant struggle against the Fomorians, ancient gods of death and darkness. In the Greek myth of the Titanomachy, the Olympian gods defeat the Titans, an older and more primitive divine race, to establish cosmic order. The Gods of Mount Olympus represents good while their antitheses are the Titans, representing evi. Rishi Kashyap and Kronos An interesting fact is that in both these mythologies, both good and evil are fathered by the same person. In Hinduism, the Devas and the Asuras are both supposed to have been fathered by Rishi Kashyap.  Krishna, Kanss and Kronos, Zeus In Hindu mythology, King Kanss of Mathura is foretold that the eighth son of his sister Devaki will kill him, hearing which, King Kanss not only imprisons both Devaki and her husband Vasudeva, he also goes about systematically killing all new babies born to his sister, till the eighth - Bhagwan Krishna - is born. Devaki and Vasudeva help each the baby to safety. A grown-up Krishna comes back to kill his uncle Kanss .  In similar fashion, Kronos becomes aware of a prophecy that he will be overthrown by one of his children. In order to avert this fate, he begins to swallow each one of his children as soon as they are born. When the sixth child Zeus is born, Rhea (Kronos' wife) devises a plan to save the baby with the help of Kronos' mother Gaia. Let me answer from a literature standpoint. These epics were NOT written with a historical perspective. The writing style is not such. For  example, Ramayana starts with a build-up for Rama as someone who is  ever virtuous, following dharma, and so on. This is a plot device.In Mahabharata war, Bheema throws some 200 conches at once and Arjuna fires some 1000 arrows at once. These are plain exaggerations. We can reasonably call these works historical fiction, like Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra, or Julius Caesar: Based on some true events but exaggerated with poetic liberties.  This  is not a fringe opinion, it's very much mainstream. It seems even  authors back in time looked at them NOT as historical manuscripts, but  as poetry. One such literary evidence is that future adaptations  (I don't want to call them translations) of these epics in other  languages like Andhra Mahabharatam (Telugu), Molla Ramayanam (Telugu),  etc., changed certain events in the story, added new events and removed  certain existing ones for character development, drama, and as per  poets' ideological point of view. Authors/poets don't do this when they think the work is supposed to be a historical document and that they are translating it.  If  someone writes one's own creative version of Indian freedom struggle,  for eg., something like "Salt rained from the heavens after Gandhi  finished his march to Dandi with a deep desire to liberate India from  oppression and guide towards independence", that would be an exaggerated  poetic description of the Salt satyagraha, not a historical one.

Are Mahabharata and Ramayana  mythology? I am often vexed by this term. We don't have enough evidence yet acceptable by mainstream audience to call them History. But then that could be limitation of archaeological studies.  But given their impact on the culture and civilization of Bharat and that they are still living values of our life, to consider them as myth also seems fallacious. Hence they are based on belief and faith of the people. In the puranic framework also, the ramayana and the mahabharata are part of the Ithihasa literature. Be it Rama sethu, or a few archaeological sites in sri lanka, remnants of Dwaraka etc are some evidences which we have now, but are they really a testimony that these two epics happened? Instead of all this, I think that adopting the values mentioned in those epics in our lives is much more important than thinking about whether they really happened or not.

Talking about the RAMAYANA and THE MAHABHARAT, we actually have no scientific discoveries that shows that these two stories actually happend. The most attractive and peculiar thing about these two epics is that these are written so beautifully that each incident happening in these stories have a previous planning behind them. Here is an example of a story of LAXMAN’s death in RAMAYANA with the reason why Laxman should die first before RAM: After Sita was consumed by Mother Earth, Ram knew that his duties on Earth were over and he decided to return back to Vaikunth, but that couldn’t be accomplished as Hanuman won’t allow Yam, the God of Death to meet Ram. To distract Hanuman, Ram threw his ring in the underworld (Paatal) and asked Hanuman to procure it. Ram then invited Yam, but he put forth a condition that the conversation between them must remain unrevealed and if anyone intercepts the conversation, Ram would kill the person. Ram asked Laxman to guard the gate to ensure no one came in to intercept the meeting of Lord Ram and Yam. In the meantime, angry sage Durvasa came in to meet Ram only to be halted by Laxman. Angry Durvasa warned that he would curse Ayodhya if not allowed to meet Lord Ram. Seeing the situation, Laxman decided to go and talk to Ram and hence intercepted the meeting. After this incident, to fulfil his brother’s promise, Laxman went to Saryu and gave up his life. Laxman’s death before Ram’s was necessary as the Shesh-Naag (the seat of Vishnu) that was Laxman had to return first, before Vishnu returned to Vaikunth. Vishnu here was Lord Ram. HERE IS ANOTHER STORY THAT LINKS BOTH THE EPICS BEAUTIFULLY: Bali, the elder brother of Sugreev, known for his strength, had a boon that whosoever engaged in a combat with him would lose half of his strength to Bali. Invincible Bali was challenged once by Ravan for a combat. Enraged Bali, grabbed Ravan by his head and took him round the world, making Ravan accept his defeat. Bali, when took over Sugreev’s wife and the kingdom of Kishkinda forcefully, Sugreev fled the kingdom and met Hanuman in the woods for help. In the interim, Ram killed a demon named Kadambh in the forest while searching for Sita and a curse-free Kadambh now asked Ram to meet Sugreev to help him from Bali. Ram decided to execute Bali after meeting Sugreev. Ram shot Bali from behind the tree, and Bali alleged that Ram had betrayed him as he didn’t challenge Bali for a combat. To this, Ram explained that if a man ill-behaves a woman, it is the duty of a righteous man to punish him. Ram then promised Bali that in his next life, he would become the reason of Vishnu’s death and thus take revenge of this incident. Bali was later reborn as Jara, the hunter, who was the reason of Krishna’s death in the Dwapar Yug! There are many stories you can find like this one in both the epics. This is the beauty of the two epics. All the incidents, all the actions taken by any character in the story have reasons behind them or have another story behind them. This beauty and accuracy of both the epics makes us believe in them. THIS IS MY POINT OF VIEW FOR BOTH THE EPICS. OTHERS MAY HAVE DIFFERENT VIEWS ON THE EPICS AND I RESPECT ALL.

The above image and its subsequent claims do not correlate. The bridge is merely a build up of sedimentary excess and was most certainly not built by an army of monkeys and humans working together. Any student of history must learn to separate fact from fiction in order to glean scientifically accurate data. In the instances of the Indian mythologies, there is a lot that needs to be weeded before we even begin to go through claims of authenticity. The supernatural aspects all need to go completely. So to conclude,while these mythologies might contain shards and wisps of historically accurate information, they are for most part, just stories and myths and nothing more.

Maybe most of the original pre-historic records, scriptures and archeological evidences were lost during this cataclysmic event… Any references to the agrarian way of life or locations, could have been part of what got introduced into the fragmentary remnants of these scriptures, while sages like Valmiki and Vyasa, reconstructed them as epics, few millennia after Pralay.

It is not entirely fictional . It is believed to be a tale based on a famous war that occured in the post Vedic era. which was sufficiently famous to have involved all the then principalities . The existence of the Kuru and Panchala tribes is attested by other semi-historical documents . The tale of the Mahabharata is said to have become after the charioteers of the war became peace time singers and poets and travelled to various parts of the country for livelihood ( a known mode of occupation at that time ) . However the Mahabharata account has undergone multiple revisions since the first time it was written . The Bhagwat Gita itself was inserted into it much later . In its present version it simultaneously a record of practices in that age , a critique of those practices, a treatise on morality , society and philosophy as well as a prescription for society to maintain harmony and stability . Thus nothing save fragments of historicity survive . Even the figure of Krishna is based on multiple “heroic” figures of that era but amalgamated from multiple sources . For example his role as the cowherder comes from the tales of a historical-legendary hero figure of a tribe in western India which was famous for its expertise in cattle rearing .Some of the places mentioned in the tale are known historical places — Gandhara from where Shakuni and Gandhari came extends between Pakistan and Afghanisthan , Magadha is a known powerful prinipality of Ancient India and so on . However its best not to treat it as literal history .

Hinduism has got a galaxy of literature ranging from ‘Sruti’ (like the vedas,upnishads, Gita etc) to ‘Smitri’ ( like Mahabharata, Ramayana Puranas etc) trying to understand and explain the Hindu Philosophy. Sruti and Smitri are the result of meditative musings and the memories of saints respectively. They are so old that their chronology can be established. However, Ramayana & Mahabharata come from smriti, so it is less authoritative. They have been compiled during Gupta phase. Like all other sacred texts they also attempts to explain Hindu philosophy but in layman language with personification of the nitty-gritty of it so that it reaches the common man. Based on the then available findings and the knowledge of Hinduism, Valmiki would have connected the dots. The same goes for the Mahabharata as well. Talking about Ramayana, its roots can be traced in various mythological tales like the one below : Once there was a mighty demon named Jalandhar called shivansh ( part of Shiva). His strength and prowess emanated from his wife Vrida( today worshipped as Tulsi) who was a chaste. It is so called that her chastity was protecting the life of her husband. The only way to overpower and kill Jalandhar was to destroy the chastity of his wife. Lord Vishnu descended from Vaikuntha and took the form of Jalandhar and went on to live in Vrinda while Jalandhar was in the battle field. Unable to recognise Vishnu, she lost her chastity. Later on when the real identity of Vishnu was revealed to her; enraged she set herself on fire and cursed Vishnu that like her husband would torment after losing her, one day his wife would meet the same fate. Hence to pay for the vices Vinshu and Lakshmi took birth as Ram & Sita respectively in the following birth. (This is also the philosophy of Karamic balance in Hinduism and prepares the ground of the epic Ramayana.) The saint Valmiki might have taken the story forward; who knows ? The Ramayana like the above tale takes up another aspect of Hinduism i.e Dhama or Duty. Here you will find a righteous Son, a brother, a father, a wife and even the vicious demon Ravana has some virtues. In conclusion I believe all this is philosophy encompassing the various truths and facets of life. Not to be taken literally but figuratively. If you merely run after the debate of whether it’s fictitious or real, you will make the mistake of not driving home the larger message hidden therein.

For us living in these times, the two great Itihasas can be read, evaluated and decide on the right practices that can be applied to the modern days. Understanding the vedic concepts of sathyam, dharma, law and order, justice, right action and coming to a conclusion the right living, we can apply, modify the practices and live a peaceful life.

The Mahābhārata Sanskrit: महाभारतम्, Mahābhāratam, pronounced is one of the two major Sanskrit epics of ancient India, the other being the Rāmāyaṇa.It narrates the struggle between two groups of cousins in the Kurukshetra War and the fates of the Kaurava and the Pāṇḍava princes and their successors. Along with the epic Rāmāyaṇa, it forms the Hindu Itihasa. It also contains philosophical and devotional material, such as a discussion of the four "goals of life" or puruṣārtha (12.161). Among the principal works and stories in the Mahābhārata are the Bhagavad Gita, the story of Damayanti, an abbreviated version of the Rāmāyaṇa, and the story of Ṛṣyasringa, often considered as works in their own right.
